segments.text: Daniil Dankovsky, the Bachelor
The Executor
How am I brave?
Time to say goodbye? Why so soon?
That's rather unkind of you. My courage never faltered in the first place.
You are a brave man, doctor. I'm glad to see you've finally mustered up the courage to do it. Meaning it's probably time to say goodbye, right?
I'm a doctor. I've been fighting death my whole life. And I usually succeed.
I don't know... What is proper when dealing with death? Punching its sorry bony face seems like the best option.
Well, you are going to die now. Death is awaiting you downstairs, by the exit.\nI wonder if you'll manage to give it the proper answer this time.
My plans were disrupted by a freak accident. If only I could re-live this bloody day...
What are you driving at?
I can still fix it!

You are a great doctor, there's no denying that. A skilled fighter of death. The plague almost devoured this town, but you managed to protect the Stone Yard from the infection, creating an impenetrable citadel here. But take a peek outside—and you'll see that people are still dying. Why do you reckon that is?
I usually succeed. I'm not used to defeat.
Can you even exit this house? I'm not sure if you can.
I understand the nature of death wrong? I'll have you know that I'm a thanatologist—and one of the best in the world, at that. Very few people in this valley of tears know more about death than I do.
You're claiming to be non-human, I gather?
You understand the nature of death wrong. You're even using the very word wrong. You people are bad at dying.
Seeing and even touching death is my job. I'm used to it. And habits desensitize emotion.
I'd rather kill it.

How many times do I have to repeat myself? There is a staggering difference between you and me. I fear no death. You, it awaits at the exit.\nYou'll get a chance to take a look at it... touch it even. And then you will cease to be, I suppose.
Are you suggesting I choose a more manageable foe? No. This is not my style.
I'm tired of your steppe poetry. Let me through, please.
Yes. I want to exterminate death. And I'll do just that, rest assured.

You made a mistake. Fought the wrong enemy. What do I have to do to get through to you...\nYou want to exterminate death, yet you drag it behind like a tethered bull. That's just... not the right way.
Any Saturday is followed by a Sunday.
It's not over yet. I can turn it good still.
Let it wait. I'm in no hurry.
Farewell, doctor. You were a good man, but your eyes were stitched shut.\nGo down now. Death is getting restless. Evil Saturday, foul Saturday...
Shrew
Sleepy Head
Merchant
Disgruntled Man
Excuse me?
If you do, it will be your loss first and foremost.
You're playing with fire, big shot. If the shop ain't open in an hour, we'll tear it down.
Who told you the threat is no more?
I seem to have misplaced the key...

The people are starving. The children are starving. What was distributed the day before yesterday, gone now. You closed everything due to the threat of the infection.\nThe threat is no more, so open the shop back. Or we will simply dismantle it. Our patience is running thin.
It's the empty can that makes the most noise. Rumor-mongering is worse than infection, it only promotes panic.
No need to badmouth him. It's not the Judge who is in charge of supplies, but rather his assistants. I'll talk to them.

Eh... dunno. But I know that the Judge, Georgiy Kain himself lifted the quarantine. Unlocked the isolation ward, dismissed the orderlies. So let him open the shop! If he doesn't, we'll break it open. Three huge bags of millet in there, and flour, too. The people know everything.
It's you who are playing with fire now, good lady.
Ungrateful bastards. All of you.
If you don't open it. we'll get to you, too. You got yourself special treatment, ain't you? Don't play with fire, big shot.
As far as I know, the Kains eat nothing but millet soup these days. The rest was given out to an angry mob like yours.
It's not the Judge's area of responsibility, it's the committee's... They're right outside the Crucible, atop the stairs. I'll talk to them, just don't do anything stupid.
Go to the Judge then, big shot! He'll open the shop. And let him give out his stock, too. The Kains got milk, grain, fresh veggies, meat even! Got it all stocked! The people know everything!
Disgruntled Woman
...Oh, so you judged?
What have you done, Georgiy! I erected every possible defense so diligently! And it is all ruined now—everything I worked to achieve!
So you agree that the plague is already upon us? How do you know?
There's a carrier here. Where are they?

I dropped by your place at dawn, Bachelor. Wanted to warn you of my plans. Your young assistant asked me not to disturb you. I judged that it was better to let you have some rest. The catastrophe has already struck, and you needed all the strength you could muster to face the trials of today.
I'm listening.
Themistocles, I know. He met a rather gruesome end, by the way. Died of plague.

Quite so. For I am the Judge. And, as is commonly agreed upon, I boast a certain level of intelligence. It's plain to me that you are on the verge of shredding me into pieces. But still your wrath. As a great Athenian once said, "Strike, if you will, but hear."
...I can't believe my ears. You let him go? Why in the world...?
Indeed. A frightened and odd-looking man begged me for shelter yesterday. I let him go.
A different angle? Such as...?
An epidemic brings death. Let epidemologists venerate new lifeforms. To me, it's a calamity, and I'm truly surprised that a ruler such as yourself doesn't share my opinion.

You are a fanatic, Bachelor. A crusader. You whole life is a duel with death. I know, I've read your articles. Followed your progress in the Capital. For many years you've been trying to eliminate the very phenomenon of death. You continue this war of yours in this town, too. But I implore you to look at this problem from a different angle.
An exam? Explain yourself. This is a rather unexpected interpretation of a catastrophe that took away half the population of your town.
How about sharing your elaborate theory with the people lying in mass graves across the river? Oh wait. They won't be able to hear you.
A plague is just a type of death to you. But to me, it's essentially an exam. And one must not run away from exams forever. Sooner or later, one must take them.
And yet you act as though you detest it.
And yet you lifted the quarantine, exposing your creation. Would you put your own child on train tracks, too? Just to check? Because it's not entirely impossible it wouldn't survive?

I have built this town, Bachelor. It's very unusual, you have to admit. This imponderable tower is its crowning achievement. And it was I who envisioned it like this. Surely you do not allow the thought that I do not care for it? This is my life's work! There's nothing in the world more dear to me.
So you think the epidemic is a punishment for the attempt? This is Old Testament logic.
Are you playing God?
Towns are like people. Some are common and plain—content with their plainness. Others try to prevail over their nature. Grow. Reach for the sky.
Georgiy, have you gone crazy?
Common sense.
And yet your town has obviously failed it.
Perhaps a town can pass it, yes. But what about single individuals? The mere mortals? Are those who do not strive for godhood unworthy of living?
Don't jump to conclusions. This isn't a punishment; this is an exam. Can't you tell the difference? An exam can be passed—and then one can move forward.
Don't you care for the casualties? According to my statistics, some 15,000 people have died. Your compatriots. Your followers.
Let us not jump to conclusions.
...Understand it?
...Master it?
...Bargain with it?

My heart aches for them. This is dreadfully cruel. But perhaps the thing we are trying to build can only be erected with the help of those who have passed it—the exam of death. Who has learned not to fight it, like you do; not to deny it, but rather...
You are truly, utterly mad.
You make a reasonable point. And it just gave me an idea... Nevermind though.

No. Embed it into themselves. Use it. Humanity has learned to use the law of gravity, hasn't it? There is your proof, just look out of the window. There was a time when humans could not brave the sky. But that time has passed.
All right. Speak.
No, it was Pericles. You are a learned man, but history is not your strong suit. Which is why you should listen to me. Perhaps it will help you see something that you missed in your previous studies.
Or a hangman...?
No. An obstetrician.
Georgiy Kain, the Judge
Sentry
Marat Ranin
Dora Feugel
Is that so? Why?
Same here. What are you doing here? Why have you all abandoned your duties?
I can't believe my eyes.
...Signed by me, right? Because if it isn't, that means you're way out of line, executing random orders.
Sounds like nonsense. In any case, you can burn this paper.

According to our papers... One moment, please, I'll find the precise... Ah, here it is! "After a short burst of fever, having woken up from anxious dreams, Bachelor Daniil Dankovsky passed away in hiw own bed, yesterday after nine o'clock, as the only known victim of the sand plague."
...And drink to my memory. I'm touched. Moved almost to tears.
What victory? Nothing's over yet!
Look around, you morons! It's beginning already!

Since no signs of the sand plague were located in the Stone Yard, the Orderly Committee have unanimously decided to disband the medical worker corps. The most committed orderlies went across the river to transport dead bodies. The least committed ones went home. As for us, we've stayed here to celebrate your victory...
Now listen to me. The threat is still very much present. Moreover, I'm quite positive that there is a carrier in the Stone Yard. Get back to work.
Keep talking in this vein and it's your demise that will be untimely. Not according to the papers, mind you. I'll shoot you with my own hand.
What...? I don't believe you. The Judge wouldn't.
Since your untimely demise, Bachelor, Judge Georgiy Kain has become our direct supervisor. He cancelled your quarantine measures. Ordered a ceasefire, so to speak.
How about getting your peepers open, you cretin? Here I am, alive, right in front of you!
...Oh, you got it all in writing! Obviously that means that nothing humanly possible can be done here. How silly of me.

I don't know... According to the Judge's orders, there's nothing more to be done here. And in the case of Bachelor Dankovsky's death the Judge is the only person whose orders I'm supposed to follow. Here, see? I got it all in writing. Legal stuff.
Official my arse... I'm going to the Judge to set this straight. And you will be punished severely for this break of conduct.
The Judge is unwell. He's raving. I'm telling you this as a doctor, I just paid him a visit. So get back to work at once! Do the rounds and send one of your people to me as an assistant.

Fine. You've convinced me. Well, since I'm dead, it's within the scope of your responsibilities to attend my place personally to oversee the funeral. Someone will have to take care of the bodies when the worst happens...
I don't know what you're talking about. I got it all in writing. Anyone can impersonate Bachelor Dankovsky. As for me, I'm just standing my watch. As an official representative.
"Legal paperwork" my arse... where did it even come from?
Nope. Legal paperwork.
That I will. As for you, get back to doing the rounds. Immediately.
You're welcome to pay him a visit and see for yourself.
Orderly-in-Chief
My good people, who exactly are you planning to bury? I'd like to examine them first.
...And I doubt that's because I'm a brilliant conversationalist. Let us not waste any time, lead the way.
Is the dancing in my honor, too? I can see that someone's dancing over there, behind your back.
You are the doctor. We've been expecting you.
And I can appreciate your husband's choice. Any sane person would prefer the noose to dealing with your steppe traditions.
"Until the evening"? And then let him die, right?
Clearly you're quite fond of your dear husband.
No. First you will listen. My husband doesn't want you to treat him. He refuses to live.\nWe need him to live until the evening. You will help.
All right, let's get to it. Where is he?
I see. Clearly the stories of the steppe people not being susceptible to the sand plague turned out to be false.
Yes.
Enough. Where is he?
He sounds like a good man. But I have a strong suspicion his affliction is incurable.
I do not understand my husband. He loves his sister too much. More than his people.
It's nice to have everything decided for you.
I'm not omnipotent. Don't pin all your hopes on me.
Go to the yurt. You are the doctor. You will help.
Herb Bride

[Try and operate without the items required, using makeshift bandages and hoping for the best. One of the steppe people offers you a crooked needle and something like a tourniquet, but they're barely sufficient.]
[You have everything you need. Proceed with the operation.]
[Leave.]

[The creature is breathing heavily. A deep and dirty wound is gaping across its belly. No one's bothered to dress it. To operate on him, one would require clean bandages and painkillers. And you'll have to move fast.]
Damn it to hell... I knew, didn't I...?
I'm sorry...
[..................\nThere is an internal bleeding. The creature dies.]
[Continue.]
Who did this to you? The wound looks suspiciously self-inflicted.
Mistake. This is most certainly me. Now please shut up and let me do my work.
...Not you.
I'm not cutting you open, I'm stitching you closed. So please calm down, we can do without your moronic superstitions.
"Go away"? Are you for real? Fine. I'm leaving. Do whatever you want.
The one who did this for you definitely knew though. An impressive wound. Was it one of your lot?
Not know the lines. Not know how to cut open. Go away.\nOutsider.
...You know what? You're right. I don't have to deal with all this.\nTo hell with you.
Like hell I will. You dragged me here, so I'll see it through to the end.
Family business. Leave.
...Here you go. All right, all done. Perhaps you'll live now, big guy.
Wedding? Not yours, obviously, so why should you worry?
Leave. Let die.\nIf I die, then no wedding.\nFew of us left.
All done. No drinking until the evening. No touching stitches. No gratitude expected, either.
All done. You are lucky to have such a caring wife, Worm.
No. Not mine...
...Right. I've spoiled everything. Of course.
I'm touched. A patient's gratitude is the most rewarding thing a doctor can hear.
Enemy. Spoiled everything.
Odongh
Orderly
Herb Bride
I'm not here to have fun.
A local custom, huh?
All right. I'm turning my back and closing my eyes.
No place for you here.\nA wedding. Not for you to watch.
Shar Shuvuu
I'm quite content with my given name, thank you.
Moga. Lovely. Very evocative.
Look, brethren. A snake-man comes.\nLet us call him Moga.
Shaazgai
Odongh
Sergeant
Committee Clerk
What? If what you're saying is true, why the bloody hell is the Judge doing what he is doing? Why is he cancelling my orders?
Perhaps he's not as mad as you think.
Finally! It feels nice to find someone both influential and like-minded. Was this the reason for his late-night visit?
The Judge has lost his mind, Bachelor. He denies the obvious. Claims that the epidemic is still here...
Quite so. I would very much enjoy offering the Judge a good bloodletting now!
Just let me in.
I know very little. The Judge's is a brilliant mind. Master used to be extremely shrewd and conscientious. Help him, doctor. Perhaps pills or leeches are in order? A bloodletting, maybe...?
...What? What did you say? I want to hear it once again! Has your master truly gone mad?
Ha ha. You have an odd sense of humor.

He went to warn you that he's relieving the quarantine, cancelling your orders. He disbanded the soldiers. Unlocked the Cathedral. Sent the orderlies away to the other side of the river. Master is a very kind man.
Doorkeeper
"Wicks"?
No.
Those are not "my" beakheads. They're on their own. Orderlies. I'll ask them.
Good day, sir. They say your beakheads raided a den in the Atrium last night, found a huge bunch of them wicks. Did they...?
I don't know. Never heard a thing about a raid.
Who knows, perhaps they did.

Them infected gits. Got themselves a pretty lil' nickname, they did. The ones that are burning 'n hiding away from the quarantine are "wicks". Those who cover themselves in rags, the responsible ones, are "mites", as in "dynamite". So, did the beakheads really snatch themselves a bunch of wicks?
Indeed? But why?
Who gave the order? I was told yesterday that General Block passed away.
And look at us here, guarding the drugstore, our bunch. The order's that not a thing is to be taken away from the store. Terrible danger.
Bacteria samples?! What in the world are you talking about? How moronic does one have to be to bring them here?
All right, I'll check.
Um... They brought your samples here, I believe? The plague vials?
I see... what a pointless loss.
Why?
'Ndeed he has... the man's been bulletproof for so many years, but the plague finally got to him, bless his soul. Captain Longin is in charge now. He gave the order too.
Don't worry, I have your head covered.
I need medicine, not the plague test-tubes.

I'm just doing my duty, sir. If this is an inspection, I can let you in. Will have to search you after though, sorry 'bout that in advance. Safety measures 'n all. Nothing is to be taken from the store. Not a single item.\nI mean, personally I respect you, but the orders were clear. No one wants to have their head court-martialled.
Can we strike a bargain, perhaps...?
Go ahead, do your thing. I've always dreamt of being searched like a common thug...
Sorry, doctor, but I'm going to have to search you. Nothing's to be carried out of the store. I warned you, so no hard feelings, eh?
I can see that General Ashes has nurtured an unwavering spirit in you lot.
It's not like I'll be the one to regret this.
No. Hands up, please.
Guard
Sort of.
And who are you, lad?
"Old man"? Really? As a person way above your rank, I am to be addressed as "Your Excellency".
Old man...? Psst, hey? Sir? Lend me an ear, will ya...? You're, like, the head guy here, right?
What for? If you're sick, you're not taking powders, you're coming with me.
Well, what does it have to do with me?

Look, old man... You're, like... Ugh. Listen, that drugstore, they have medicine there, like powders. I mean, it's not like everything got stolen, right? Something has to remain. \nBut that twat of a soldier is a vigilant jerk. And I need powders!
Your Auntie, huh?
I'm sending 'em 'cross the river, to my Auntie.
You'll wait for me? Yeah, right. I require a more inventive scam to be fooled.
You drop these silly ideas right now. And shoo! The last thing I want is to see you get yourself killed...
I'll get the items I need without your help just fine.

You tell the soldier, he'll let you in. 'Tis not in his interest to get on your bad side. 'N then you can, like, throw all that you find to me from the window. There's a broken window upstairs. We'll split the profit! I'll wait for you down there.
And what might you want, Cookaroo, Khan Kain's best friend?

Ugh, you urchins! I'm fed up with you. Roaming around like you've got nothing better to do, breaking the quarantine, spreading infection. Being the first ones to die, I might add, and dragging your families along, too! What, am I wrong?
I'm Cookaroo, I'm local. Khan Kain's best friend. You ask around, everyone knows me.
I don't smoke. Go home and leave me alone.
Still not convinced.
We'll discuss your smoking habits if I find you waiting for me when I return. Let's try this great heist of yours.

I mean it. Word! There's no other way to get anything from that drugstore. We can help each other. C'mon, old man...!\nEveryone knows me here, you just ask around, Cookaroo's a man of his word, they'll tell you! \nI'll wait by the window, I promise. Got a cig?
...Not convinced. You run along now.
A smart lad, are you? All right, deal.
'Tis not in my interest to get on your bad side either.
I think you're lying, punk.
Helping you is the only way, huh? All right, I'll buy it.

Nuh huh! You won't. This store's the only place that's got anything useful, but you'd be arsed to smuggle the lousiest bottle out past that jerk of a soldier. 'Tis either with my help or not at all. So...?
Cookaroo
...Seems like I have to admit to the truthfulness of prophetic dreams now. Where and when did you get infected?
Not to you. To me, there is. And to all the people outside.
I worked so bloody hard to save the last patch of infection-free land in this damn town! Do you even realize what you've done...? Why did you have to hide?
...And then there were three. Stay with us, doctor. There's nothing to be afraid of, you'll see.
You're lying. This is the sand pest. It's incurable.
What do you mean, "well"? You're doomed.
We don't know... Is it important? It's almost over. We're almost well.
You're lying. This is the sand pest. It's incurable.
Of course you're not going anywhere! You're leaving this house feet first.
We're not going anywhere. We don't need to. It's almost over. We're almost well.
Exactly. These are fatal symptoms.
...I'd kill you with my own hands if I could.
Everything's gone now. There's no fever. No pain. No fear. Only elation.\nLook at my sister. Look how much better she feels now. She can almost keep her head up. Can almost stand.
Lotman
What's this?
...Who gave the order?
What were you burning?
I believe it's wood.\nNot like anyone can tell now...
Who does? Who says that?
No. I didn't give such an order.
You did, they say. This is being done in your name.
Did they show you a paper? Signed by me? Damn it...
The orderlies? The masked ones? Huh...
Your lot came here. The orderlies, I mean, the "Talon" guys. \nThey do.
My orders...?
I ordered you to burn signal fires at suspicious locations! What happened here?
I mean... It's best not to look, I guess.\nWood. Logs. Per your orders.
Oh, I'll get to the bottom of this!
This is it. No more fires from this point on.
Yes, fires. Per your orders.\nYou ordered for the fires to burn, didn't you? Here you go...
Watchman
Committee Clerk
Committee Clerk
What thing?
I know... The infection found its way here! And its carrier must be around, perhaps walking the streets right now...
Doctor, wake up. A bad thing happened.
The dream comes true... Who is this Blacky person?
We'll see about that... Where is he?
Whether it's the sand thing or not is for me to decide. But well done, lad, waking me up immediately. An hour of hesitation could have cost us the town's life.
Blacky's old man is ill. But it's not plague. I mean, not the sand thing.\n...Will you cure him? And not send beakheads after him?
And why would that be?
Oh no, you're not walking me anywhere. You're staying put, right here. You were in contact with an infected person! I'll examine you later.
Right there in the Neck yard. The first house, over there, you can see it from the doorway.\nI'd walk you there but I can't. We shouldn't be seen together.
I see... Yes, the orderlies' reputation is rather bleak.
You do understand, don't you, that the fate of the whole town—or what's left of it—depends on how quickly patient zero is isolated? \n...Thanks for at least telling me about the patient.
Because. You'll bring the beakheads to the Blackers and they'll say it was me who ratted them out. No one'll talk to me after that.
Mind your manners, young man!
I'm not going to repeat myself. You're staying in. And don't talk back to me!
It's not the sand thing with him, I'm telling you! Geez!
Really? Sounds odd. All right. I'll deal with your Blacky first and than pay a visit to the Crucible.
What do you mean, "stopped him"? What if it was important? Are you out of your mind, lad? Do you appreciate what's at stake here?
Also, the Judge was here. Demanded you be woken up. I stopped him.\nDidn't like how the old geezer looked at all. Nuts, is how he looked, hands shaking and all.
There's a carrier of the plague in the town! I mean... perhaps. That's what my intuition tells me. Anyway, now is not the time to be flippant at all!
All right. An hour is not much. I'll look into it.
He looked completely nuts, I'm telling you. And you looked dead tired.\nThe Judge was here an hour ago or so anyway, must be at his place now. It's next door.
Sticky
Sticky
Beakheads? Is this the monicker you've given the orderlies? Don't be afraid of them, they are public servants. Doing a good job, too.
Is that your father?
It's not the sand pest. Don't tell 'em beakheads!\nHe'll get better. I know it.
Where's your mother?
When did he get sick?
Stepfather. Same thing.\nHe brought me up. Provided for me.
Pah! Stop bossing me around...
Here's to hoping...
Hell if I know... Now c'mon, go ahead 'n make him better!
All right, shush. Let's take a look at your old man.
When did he get sick?

Nothin' good 'bout their job. A fast job, is what they do. You just sneeze—'n here they are, grabbin' you with them hooks, draggin' to the ward.\n'N 'tis where the sick are. So the only way out of there is feet first.
Sounds bad.
Merely an hour? This is good news.
An hour ago or so. Dropped down 'n started beating 'n flopping like a fish, mouth open 'n all.\nI brought him water, but he couldn't tell it was me...
Blacky
Thoughtful Odongh
Rowdy Man
Rowdy Man
Aspity
Are you out of your mind?
What paper? Where am I supposed to get such a paper?
Sign a paper, sir, please. For me. I'll show it to my mum. I'll show her that I didn't shoot.
How many were killed?
After your shift is over, go to the Crucible. They'll sign it for you there.
No, sir. I'll show my mum so that she knows I didn't kill anyone. Please sign a paper.
Why would you need such a paper? To frame it on the wall?
All right, all right...
I was recruited yesterday, I'm a local! You can just leave, and I'll have to live with the aftermath!\nIt were the real soldiers who did the shooting...
Damn...
I don't do signing.
...A lot.
Sentry
What children?
Good. You'll be relieved of your duty soon.
The children are asleep. All is quiet.
Who is in charge of their well-being? Are they fed? Provided water?
What tower?
Oh... A towerful of children. Right-o. How could I forget.
Eh? The children in the tower. Over there.\nSeveral hundred. No entry.
At ease.
I see.
No one reports that to us.
Cura te ipsum. Heard the phrase? It's about me.
I'm fine. It's you who's overworked.
...Doctor, are you... I mean... umm...\nWhat about you? Who takes care of you if you feel unwell or have a headache?
Polyhedron Sentry
Orderly No. 12
How rude. Ungratefulness is the worst sin.
Wrong. As long as I'm the only doctor in this town, everything's my business.
Whatcha looking at? Move along. Our business here, not yers.
Watch your tongue! Perhaps you need jailtime to cool your head off?
It hasn't been easy on you, I know. Please stay patient some more.
Ye ordered to lock the shop yesterday, didntcha? Well, lo and behold. 'Tis locked.\nSo why did ye come? An exception, are ye? Locked for everyone but ye? Ye big-city fucker...
Disgruntled Man
So you came for the cure. Are you sick?
What's inside?
I came here before you. But you may go in first. I need to pluck up my courage.
So this Aspity is a dream-teller, huh?
"Aspity"? Who's that?
No, I'm not sick. I came here so that Aspity would explain my dream to me. We all did.
So what did you dream of?
"Dream truths"? "Dream lies"? What are you talking about?
What a curious coincidence. I also happened to dream of a rather frightening thing today.\nThanks for letting me cut the queue. I will indeed have a chat with this individual.
Indeed. I dreamed of a frightening thing today. Only Aspity can tell dream truths from dream lies.
If you tell me what you dreamed of, you can have any item of mine. I'll even let you choose which one.
A truly outstanding gift... And, well, you have every right not to tell me.

That is my business, not yours. Even if I told you, it would be pointless. You would only hear dream lies.\nAspity, on the other hand, can see your dream with her own eyes. So it doesn't matter which words you use to describe it.
Ah! I see... Of the sand plague, I believe?
Same here.
I dreamed that I would die today. And that I wouldn't be the only one.
Sounds reassuring.
Well, thank you. Take your time plucking up all the courage you need.
You look healthy. That's a relief. But I think you'd better find a more suitable place for your future conversations with this dream-teller of yours.
No. Aspity taught us how not to fear that bogeyman. There is no sand plague.\nI saw death by fire.
And you're expecting this... family reunion to go less than smoothly, I gather?
Tonight, Aspity came here. Sahba-ötün, our mother and the mistress of dreams.
What about you? What did you dream of?
Ugh, the steppe superstitions strike again...
All dreams are prophetic. But ordinary people can't tell which dream-things will happen inevitably, which can be changed, and which were merely dross.
So she can see beyond the present and mundane, huh...?
Sahba-ötün. A wise woman. She knows how to see. Knows how to listen.
Believer
Damn...
I don't care. I was just passing by.
Nothing to see here, doctor. It's all over.\nA shame you weren't here earlier... but there's nothing to be done now.
Soldier
How do you know?
Here comes Bachelor Dankovsky, the man who failed to defeat death.
Really? Well, what did I do yesterday?
And what am I going to do tomorrow?
If you're so smart, kindly tell me what I am doing now.
We know all about you. We know what you did yesterday and what you are going to do tomorrow.
Go on, go on.
You don't seem to hold my achievements in high regard.

Yesterday? Stuffed our houses chock-full of refugees from across the river, forbidding them to go outside.\nRobbed our wardrobe department and dressed your medical staff as mourners. Judged the Judge...
Huh... You got everything right. Who could have guessed.
Anyone can make predictions like these. All my actions are public.
...Turned the Cathedral into an isolation ward. The Crucible, into the headquarters. The Polyhedron, an ark.\nAssigned sentries and hit the cot at dawn.
Why is that...?

Everything will be decided this evening, Excellency. A terrible appointment is in store for you, and you will not emerge from it victorious. \nIndeed, we do know the key to victory, but alas! It will be of no use to Bachelor Dankovsky.
The doleful humor is what I love your troupe for. I've heard this one a ton of times, and yet it never gets old.
How?
...There won't be a tomorrow. Today is your last day, Excellency. Please make good use of it.
You are anything but a fool.
Mine were numbered by me, written down neatly, and are now kept in perfect order.

Now? Making a fool of yourself by talking to a fool about his foolish endeavors and engaging in various tomfoolery, wasting priceless droplets of time.\nWe have very little of the latter left, by the way. Have our days been numbered by ourselves...? Or were it hours...
So if I had a softer heart, you'd teach me how to win this duel?
Only a man with an open heart can overcome such an adversary.
An outbreak doesn't seem like a good time to become soft-hearted. But I'll keep your words in mind.
I'm wasting my time here...

Maybe. Possibly. But it's useless to explain to a heartless man. ...Take heart, Excellency! If you ever find it, that is. And then come back to us... Even though it all sounds like a rather implausible turn of events.
Here... I've taken heart. Taken a heart, I mean. Undoubtedly, an open one.
Excellency...? It's so heartwarming to see you in good health.
You wanted me to come back to you with an open heart. Well, here I am.
...It looked too fitting to be a coincidence.
Oh... Excellency. What a sordid sight! Sorry for underestimating you. You definitely do have... how shall I put it... a creative touch. But this is pure madness. You can't take things so literally!
This cage is called "life." I'm in no hurry to break out of it.
You promised to help me out with this evening's appointment.

Come now, Excellency... come now! Do you think this is some sort of game? Even if it is, it most certainly is not played by your rules! A game is a cage, and if you fail to break out of it, you lose! We know what we're talking about.
Thank you. I'll think it over.
You buffoons...
Never agree to play a game if you don't understand its rules. The stakes are too high. If you already have, challenge and change those rules, Bachelor Dankovsky. Challenge and change.
What do you need then?
I wasn't planning to donate anything.
Save your spare change. We don't need money.
What if I were to switch troupes completely and join yours full-time? How about that?
The play I'm performing in is starting to wear old.

Would you really like to help? We're lacking a number of crucial performers. ...But, alas, you are already starring in a different play, Excellency. Although, in all honesty, you're far from brilliant.
In that case, would you mind telling me what these... tools of torture are for? The ones you're standing by?
I very much doubt you have anything I might need. Seems like the opposite is correct—it is I who's fulfilling your incredibly odd wishes.
We can't hire you. Not until tomorrow, anyway.\nAside from that, we're at your service, Excellency.
Is that so? Why?
These? Oh, these are merely reminders. Anchors. To avoid laxity. We are actors, so we play... yet any play, performance, or game is a cage.
What do you mean?

Bravo! Bravo, Excellency. Double score. Seems like you're beginning to understand. Now pause for a second and do your best not to forget this brilliant answer.\nIt'll save your life one day. Never play by someone else's rules, Excellency. Invent your own.
Perhaps I will.
You've given me a curious idea, mime...

Any play, performance, or game is a cage because it's played by the rules written by someone else. How can a heartless man escape such a cage? That is the question. And we are yet to find the answer. Who knows—perhaps you'll be of help in this matter.
Please be so kind as to explain clearer.
You mean that thing you said about games and cages?
We just did. A very fitting coincidence indeed.
Tragedian
Tragedian
Firemaker
Herb Bride
Guard
It's not like I have any.
Planning to take the goods with you to kingdom come...?
No money. Barter only.
Merchant
Were there victims on your watch?
Me. Carry on here.

We've been told today that there are no commanders left. When General Block was killed, Longin took the lead.\n...Now they say that Longin is also dying. All the officers are across the river. So who issues orders?
How many were killed?
Yeah... Whal else is there to say indeed.
Er... Well, the perimeter was breached a couple of times. Not as badly as the day before yesterday, but still, formidable attempts. There was shooting... what else is there to say?
What inspection? Where are the inspectors?
An inspection? From the Crucible, you mean? All right, I'll check on them.
How should I know who's dead and who's wounded! Stop twisting the knife, doctor.\nThere was an inspection, they wrote it all down. Go bother them.
I ordered no such thing...
It's not my Cathedral. I'm not a local...
How should I know? Across the river, perhaps, or in that Cathedral of yours where you gather suspicious people.\n...We, on the other hand, gather no one. We were ordered to shoot on sight.
Keep your watch.
Who did then? Everything that happens, doctor, is attributed to you. Everything...
Sentry
What kind of a machine?
Who in the world are you?
Each time I catch a glimpse of that giant clock up there, I am reminded of the fact that the Cathedral is not a temple, but rather a machine.
Really? What makes you think so?
Previously, this place served as an isolation ward for the infected, the suspected, and the ones who may have contracted the disease. I assume you're one of them?
A time machine? Are you saying it can transport me to the past or to the future? Like in that Englishman's book, what's his name...
This is a time machine. Time works differently on the inside and on the outside. It's frozen now. I think something's broken.
So you're a local religious worker?
Care to give me more details?

The people who had been brought here on your orders spent several days in this stone prison. Yet to them, it looks as though everything happened today. Time is holding its breath here, the day lingers. I've spent quite enough time in this Cathedral, sir, so I know how to spot such things.
This doesn't make sense. If they're sick, locking themselves in won't help.
This Cathedral sounds more like a cold room than a machine. A gateway protecting one from non-existence?

I am but a humble servant. I work here; I always have and always will be confined to this place, so don't worry about me. I won't go anywhere.\nThose two also refuse to leave... which means they cling to life too much. Understandable obstinacy.
How do you know?

It's not like that. The Kains have designed it to produce time. To alter it, stretch and compress it. But like all the Kains' attempts at challenging nature, it is unfinished, imperfect, and faltering.
You are either a fatalist or a fanatic. Cathedrals can't save people from plagues.
Whether they can leave or not is for me to decide, and I'd prefer to get to that.
You're quite right. If they leave this place like those poor careless souls from before, they'll simply die. There's no doubt about it.
Drawing the perfect picture of my life in this bloody town of yours.
All right, less small talk and more examining the seekers of the life eternal. What are they called anyway, Adam and Eve?

Look up, Bachelor. Can you see the clock? Its hands are frozen. Outside, they won't live to see the evening—but in here, nothing will threaten their lives until time starts running again... If you can call this pathetic feverish crawling inside a heartless stone belly "life", that is.
That'll do too.
Stand your watch.
Marat and Dora.
Perhaps this place gives them more food for thought than the outside.
I didn't come here to indulge in philosophizing, you buffoon. I just did what had to be done.
I'm not wise, just diligent.

Blessed is the dead who thinks he is alive. Why hurt their idyll? That would be too cruel. ...You are a wise man, Bachelor. If they want to live through this evil day again and again... who are we to rob them of their bliss—confusing non-existence for existence?
Same here. Curious indeed.
I'm a doctor. I know full well that they don't have much time left. The lad's case in particular doesn't look... and, honestly, the girl's isn't much better.
I took pity on them. Had a hunch that they'd simply perish here. As for out there, who knows...

You did the right thing, doctor. They left this place completely assured that they are going to die. To overcome the fear of death is a great achievement. Who knows? Perhaps this particular act of bravery is exactly what saved their lives. I'd be curious to follow their fates. Thank you.
Clockworker
Pay respects? To whom?
What's going on? Who are these people?
Did you come to pay respects?
No. I'm not.
Let me in. I want to have some sleep.
You aren't a local, are you?
The local crowd needs to check their facts better. I am Daniil Dankovsky.
Your clock is running fast. Let me in.
Daniil Dankovsky, a doctor from the capital, passed away in this house an hour ago. Would you like to come in to pay respects?\nPlease. Rituals are very important for the local crowd.
Mourner
What treatment? Who are we going to treat? Where's everyone?
What's done?
I thought you were dead.
Everything's done. I got a bit sleepy though... Sorry about that.\nShall we proceed with the treatment, doctor?
You're raving... and not making too much sense.
You need to have some rest. If you're not squeamish, you can take any bed.
Oh the condescension... Perhaps you can also enlighten me as to where the source of the outbreak was?

Don't give me that look, doctor... and don't blame yourself. I think I know why we ended up like this.\nYour attention must have slipped today. You didn't put all the pieces together. Failed to assemble the puzzle...
I don't believe they got better.
Of course they must have. They are all probably home already.
I gave the patients water and wet towels to relieve the fever. But I can't find a single one of them now... They must have gotten better and left.
"Puzzle" is not the word I would use. I'm glad you're feeling better, Dora. Now get some rest.
A shame I can't live through it all again. I'd manage to uncover the pattern connecting all the facts... but oh well.

You told us yourself, don't you remember? Everything that transpired, did so for a very good reason. The puzzle was almost solved, but some pieces must have slipped. Me, I don't even know what events you were referring to. It was your day, after all, not mine... Evil Saturday. Foul Saturday.
I'm sorry to hear that.
This is silly. I just zoned out for a moment.
So did I! About you, I mean. Marat and I came to ask you what to do next, and there you were, lying in a coffin.\nMarat snapped. He doesn't trust you anymore.
Dora Feugel
I did my best.
Stop it with the shouting.
What makes you think I've resigned to die?

Ah... so it's true? You're given up? Resigned to die? Thrown in the towel?\nThe great Bachelor Dankovsky... a celebrity thanatologist. The scientist who is claimed to have defeated death itself. Utterly failed, haven't you?
No. It is not.
This isn't a common epidemic, mate. Isn't yersinia pestis. Neither is it the Black Death. This is something completely new. You want to me overcome it in a week? How about decades!

You did nothing! The whole town hung on your every word, you were treated like a prophet. A leader. The leader! The Judge, Fat Vlad, Saburov—they all trusted you. All the while you were feeding the town to the plague, district by district... Our town has become nothing more than an arena for your duel with death. Isn't that right?
Stop it with the foam at the mouth! Or do I need to teach you good composure?
The easy way is shifting all the responsibility from your dumb heads to my shoulders!

I trusted you! We all did. For as long as you lived, so did we. I know it first hand. And now you've decided you've had enough and marched into the grave meekly, like a lamb to the slaughter! It must feel nice to find an easy way out!
Get a grip. You're a quitter and a disgrace.
Post hoc non propter hoc, as they used to say...

It all just slipped through your fingers! The disease infiltrated the Stone Yard today, but you didn't notice! Your type would never go through a back alley, your routes are always the same, from the main street to the main square and back. Perhaps you weren't really looking? Perhaps you're in league with it? The epidemic began the day you arrived in the town. I wonder if that's a coincidence...
Marat Ranin
Took them where?
Took whom away?
Done... I took them all away. Can't do no more.
I can't make heads or tails of your babbling!
This is not my house, this is a temporary place of residence. And it was I who ordered to set up hospital here. Nothing to apologize for.
They're on the other side of that door. I couldn't carry them any further, I'm exhausted.\nSorry for making such a mess of your house... But I ain't going back there. Don't make me.
What about you? How are you feeling?
Everyone.
We're not done yet. Stay alert, I may need you.
Take a break, number twelve. You are released from duty.

I'm dead tired, doctor. I haven't had a decent sleep for two days now... Any more assignments?\nWe're goners anyway, no chance to break out of here. We did all we could, but this seems to be it. Orderly number twelve, going off duty...
This epidemic destroyed eight thousand people in a week. Do you really have to ask?
There were thirteen districts in your town. Miraculously, I managed to save two. Dozens of refugees are sheltered here. There will be survivors.
Did you take the sick to the side room, you nitwit? It has no proper conditions, it's too small!
Just one more thing, doc... Reckon there is still hope?
The Lil' One
Orderly No. 12
Herb Bride
Well?
This is not a good time for reports. I'm in a hurry.
Grigory Gorky, number six. Here to report to you, doctor.
You're leaving nowhere. It's quite the opposite, actually: you're staying here to comb every suspicious nook and cranny. We've missed something. I know it.

The state of the coast is mine to evaluate. And my information differs from yours. How many of you are here in the Stone Yard? Thirty six? I need every commanding orderly to report to me, stat. You have half an hour.

Generally the coast is clear, sir. No signs of the plague.\nI'd say you've won. Congratulations are in order. As for us, we are leaving this part of the town. Our place is across the river. Still work to be done there.
...So the orderlies have deserted. And yet you have the gall to claim that everything is all right.
...There's no rest for the wicked. I never dismissed the orderlies—so why are they gone? Do my words mean nothing?

...But most orderlies are gone for good. Some of them, gone home even. Come now, doctor. Your work is done.\nTake a look at yourself! I've seen happier corpses. You're overworked and deserve a rest. A good, long, peaceful rest...
Let them stay there. Report to me when I find them. Then I'll check the suspicious spots myself.\nThe rest of you deserve to be court-martialled—you keep that in mind, number six!
...Thank god someone's heart and mind are in the right place.

There's simply nothing left to do. The coast is clear. There are several orderlies who have not abandoned their duties... they're probably still out there, guarding suspicious spots. They insist on staying unless you withdraw the orders personally, doctor. Bootlickers, if you ask me. Subservient show-offs.
Yes.
No, it was... another thing. No matter. No off you go—and start with the search! If you see anything suspicious, report to me immediately! Every hour counts now.
None of your business.
Why so tense, doctor? If I may ask?\nSome whippersnapper just rushed past me. Was it he that disturbed you?
Don't you try to be clever with me, number six. Return to your duty.
The little rascals are not to blame; irresponsible idiots like you are.

The little rascals only understand spanking, if you ask me. Gotta give them a good beating every now and then, ground them, and assume any word they utter is drivel. They're never up to any good. Lotta energy, little reason....
Indeed.
Please remind me once again where the boy came from.

Heard you loud and clear, doctor. Gather everyone I can find. Leave alone those who are standing their watch in suspicious spots; those ones you'll deal with personally. Let them stand there, waiting for you. What is there not to understand? All perfectly understandable.
I see.
There's the house, you can see it from here. Go down the path, through the brick gate, and it'll be in front of you. Street entrance.
Orderly No. 6
Your vigilance is commendable, Mikhail Goba. Report the situation.
What do you mean, "done for"?
Mikhail Goba, number two. Reporting in.\nY'know, no matter what they said, I couldn't believe you were done for... and right I was!
The Judge, cancelling my orders...? What is this about?

I've been told that you died of exhaustion. I don't remember who brought the news... but the rumor is that you burned yourself out. Protected us from the plague, but at the cost of your own life.\n...So some of the guys went to the Judge for further instructions. "Nothing to do here," he said, "Your place is across the river."
All right, I'll deal with the Judge. Now report the situation.

That's what I said too! None of his business, medicine! A smart man, that the Judge is, no arguing here; but you're the plague man. His business is power; as for the pest and other medical stuff, we are to do what you, the Bachelor, have ordered, no matter if you're alive or dead.
Tell me more.
Thank you. I've heard enough.

Reporting in. The Dusk district, house one—there it is, to the left, with the smoking chimney—is harboring Aspity, a local quack. There's a rumor circulating that she's not susceptible to the sand pest and can cure it, too.\nHouse two, to the right. A suspicious group of children is ogling its windows. They're probably up to no good...
I see... Could have guessed it myself.
Thank you. Return to your duties.
A semi-circle on a horizontal line, Bachelor. Means the sun setting.
She needs to be deported to the other side of the river immediately. I'll talk to her myself. Ans what's wrong with the children?
Sounds dangerous indeed. Good job, number two. Now go get some rest.
How long has she been here...?

This Aspity, or Sahba, is quite a character. It's plainly obvious what types she will attract... the infected types. Nimble, they are, swift like mice, won't be held back by any kind of barrier. You won't be able to stop them. I mean, look—they're already crowding her place! The mob was even larger at dawn.
...Drivel. Number two, do you really believe in magic like some sort of uneducated old wife? These are just children. Stop it with the obscurantism.
Indeed. I don't like the sound of it. I'm not that fond of children in general. But I'll deal with the quack first. She needs to be taken away—for everyone's good.
One more thing: where's your commanding orderly? Across the river?

The children are not getting enough spankings, that's what's wrong with them. They don't give a rat's arse about the adults, as you have surely noticed. It's a clear sign: wherever there are kids, there is trouble. It's just the games they play—malicious games. I wouldn't be surprised to find out this whole outbreak was just a game of theirs too.
I'll shove this party right up their...
No. They were planning to throw a small party at the cape, by the tombs.
What's wrong with the children then? You said they're ogling windows?

She came last night. I mean, you've sealed the Stone Yard, so there's no sand pest here—and consequently she has few pilgrims visiting, there's no demand for her services. But still, it would be safer to get rid of her. She's looking for trouble...
Orderly No. 2
Where is the Judge?
Can't be damned to remember your number? What's wrong with you, Likhobor? That's quite lackadaisical.
...A funeral? Who are they planning to bury?

Pankrat Likhobor, Bachelor. Can't be damned to remember my number. We got two sorts of trouble here, 'n I dunno which is worse. Firstly, the steppe people. Abandoned their camp behind the Cathedral yesterday. The ones who stayed are preparing a funeral of some sorts. Secondly, the Judge has kindly gone off his rocker. Cancels your quarantine measures... and I think he harbors an infected person, too.
Why in the world would they be invalid? Have you lost your marbles?
I don't believe the Judge would say such things.

You're being unfair, sir, what with all the big words. If I lacked anything, I wouldn't be standing here. The rest of the band went home, y'know. The Judge dismissed us 'n said all your orders were invalid.
I'll have a talk with him immediately.
For your vigilance, Likhobor, I assign you number one. Now go and get some rest. But don't burn the outfit, it'll come in handy still.
That's what I said! The Judge has always been a decent, honest man, supported us 'n all, sir. But he wouldn't say something like this in his right mind.
I'll have a word with the Judge first.
I know where their camp is, you moron. It was I who ordered them relocated there.
I see. Where's your commanding orderly?

He's home, in the workshop. Up the stairs and to the left.\n'N don't forget them steppe people too—just follow the footpath by the Cathedral, go through the apple tree garden, you'll see the place... or at least the smoke from their fires.
I see. I'll pay them a visit. Is the Judge home?
One of their lot, I s'pose. Been all over the Stone Yard, looking for you. The soldiers reminded them of their place.
I'll shove this party right up their...
As far as I know, they were planning to throw a small party at the cape, by the tombs.
Orderly No. ?
Go on. I like how you're listing my achievements. More, please?
Bachelor Dankovsky is ready to die.

So, Bachelor Dankovsky, the founder of Thanatica—a lab where you've been fruitlessly trying to solve the problem of human mortality for too many years... the tragic sand plague fighter... are you ready to die?
Was this why you sent me away to explore the town?
Oh, you're a clever one... Heh. You definitely seem to have understood something.
If we're having this very personal conversation at all, please be so kind as to tell me: how many days exactly are we talking here?

I sent you nowhere. I came here to claim you. But I don't want to do it unless you accept me. You hate death so much that you can prolong the agony for many days, surviving purely on your own hatred. Aren't you tired of this yourself?
Are you trying to tell me that when the boy woke me up...
So the kids were right...

Enough. You've had enough time to put yourself and your actions in perspective. Your thoughts keep coming back to your very last day time and again, as if you were trying to fix something. But in reality you are lying here, delirious, clinging to the naive hope that this terrible house is a product of your imagination—a prophetic nightmare.
Give me a moment. I need to collect my thoughts.
No. I refuse to. This is all a trick.

...You once again refused to die and plunged into a new loop of your deathbed derangement. Everything but this house is a product of your imagination. But now you are finally coming to. There's only one step left to make to leave the illusion behind and embrace reality. I'm afraid I'll have to be insistent. So I repeat: are you ready to die?
The Judge believes that the epidemic is a sort of an exam, testing one's ability to become superhuman.
Aspity the steppe woman claims that as long as we understand where death leads to, we keep on living.
In the morning, you told me that you're not unlike a law of nature. A rule, so to speak, of this world. Could you please remind me though, which rules exactly we're playing by?
...Do that. Thinking is never inappropriate.
I'm not Bachelor Dankovsky. You may take him. He was starting to wear on my nerves anyway.
No. I like being Bachelor Dankovsky. And a prolonged agony is preferable to an inglorious end.

Not "superhuman"—just "human", if I may kindly correct you. If only you understood the immeasurable vastness of humanity, you would never want to become something else. Are you ready to die, Bachelor Dankovsky?
Yes. I have an idea of what's beyond this place. It's undoubtedly more intriguing. I want to break out.
I want to finish what I started. Your casuistry won't trick me. I will keep fighting death—and will see it through.

Sahba-ötün is so cute... So used to nurturing little children and cubs. She begged me to take it easy on you. Said you're like a baby, who lacks the right words. Can you feel it, at least? Do you know in what direction you want to live?
I deny you the right to exist. I'm the one in control.
You're not death. You're merely a puppet. It was I who brought you to life—and it is I who will end it.
Are you ready to die, beakhead?
What on earth...?
Keep vigil over my body? What do you mean?

Yes, the kids grew very fond of you. They keep vigil over your body—even fighting over the privilege of fetching water for you. The girl is the only one smart enough to realize that it's time your torture ended... But adults always underestimate children. Think they are more intelligent. And you are no exception.
Solve the same problem in my real life, when the time comes.
Just live on. Rest in peace.
I don't know. I haven't decided yet. But thank you kindly for the enlightening conversation.
Touché. Bravo, Bachelor. ...Or are you? It's hard to tell who exactly talks to me from the other side of the glass... what a cumbersome mask. Anyway. What do you plan to do now?
You chose freedom. Congratulations.\nGive me your hand. Now the interesting part begins.
Yes. I'll stay here until the end.
I merely don't want to die.
So you want to repeat this circle once again. Well. The choice was yours to make.

Now close your eyes. When you open them, a boy called Sticky will wake you up, and the Stone Yard will once again be free of infection. Perhaps this time you'll manage to prepare yourself for the inevitable.\n\nSee you soon.
Yes. I refuse to die.
Oh, don't get me wrong, I'm very fond of thinking. You can say it's a hobby of mine. Never miss an opportunity to think some more when the chance presents itself.
So you refuse to die. Are you sure you thought this through?
Why should you care? Just reap what needs reaping.
Hard to please, aren't you?
...No. No. This is not what I meant. This is not how you were supposed to die.
And yet... This is my fault, isn't it? Do what you must.
Yeah, I agree that the attempt was lousy. Would you let me try again?

Think about it. "Are you ready to die?" This is what the question was. The wording is important here.\nYou're dying. But you aren't ready. What's the point of such death? You never braved the abyss; you fell limply down its chasm.
The Executor
And my job is making sure you remember them well. I'm all ears.
If the local populace keeps roaming the streets without a care in the world, "educating" them won't do much. Why do they act as though nothing happened?
I'm standing my watch, doctor. As per your instructions.\nMy job is to educate the local populace on the required precaution measures in times of an outbreak.
Recite the instructions.

We're understaffed. We can't make them stay in—we can only educate them. Although in my humble opinion, sir, it's all pointless now anyway. Walls won't protect anyone from the pest... poisoned air doesn't care about walls. And rats are omnipresent, too.
Uh huh. Go on.
...Only they're unavailable.

Immunity is key. This is our main defense, our tough armor. As long as it's high, there is a chance to escape unscathed.\nBut infection gnaws at it. When it becomes low, it's time to take immunity boosters. A-pills.
All right. Go on.
There were some at the drugstore. And in personal stocks too... if you manage to get to one. All in all, they're obtainable. It's hard, but doable.
Such as...?

The air itself is dangerous. Or, to be more precise, the black particles it's filled with are. They are what wears out the immunity.\nHowever, if you're already infected, it stops being a hazard. When you're infected, you need to keep an eye on other things...
Go on.
Indeed. One must keep a close eye on their infection level. The lower, the better. Please try to hammer this thought into everyone's heads.

The things that exacerbate your condition, obviously. Being touched by infected people. The mobile clots of airborne infection, the so-called "plague's breaths."\nThe more infected you are, the faster you're dying.
Go on.
Correction: There are problematic rumors circulating about some sorts of magical cures that can actually rid a person from the sand pest completely. I hope you root this hearsay out?

The level of infection is decreased by antibiotics... but they're also harmful for your health. We forbid the populace from taking too much of them, that can lead to a fatal outcome. In any case, if the infection has already found its way into your body, antibiotics cannot erase it completely.
Well, I find this chase disruptive! This data is untested and unverified. It's no good giving people false hope. Go on.
Children's powders... are children considered luminaries of medicine now? If anyone here needs to be firmly grounded, it's the children!

As a matter of fact... If you insist, sir, we will quell these rumors. But... they say it works, doctor. Using steppe traditional practices, Burakh has created a panacea. And children's powders work too. There have been cases of people getting miraculously cured. Everyone's chasing them for a reason.
Well done. As you were.

No. That's not all. You forgot to mention that a person who wants to actually do something needs to stock on painkillers. Morphine reduces pain, giving the illusion of health restoration... even though it's temporary.
What else... Immunity aside, thick clothing also protects from infection. Which is why we wear these outfits that even cover faces. I think that's all.
What kinds of orders?
I don't know. I'll drop by them and check.
No. There is no committee anymore. Ignore them.
Whatever. It can't get any worse.
Oh, and one more thing, sir. The anti-epidemic committee at the Crucible keeps on working, as far as I know.\nBut we're receiving weird contradictory orders from them. Should we still follow them?
Have they gone insane? I'll check it out.
Indeed. All these guidelines were approved by me. Get on with them.

Ahem... to breed cats. To take beds and bunks outside. To put small bells atop graves. To bury the dead in the most notable and visible places. Not an hour goes by without them issuing a new guideline.
I was too late...This is it then.
Do I hear delight in your voice, orderly...?
Here it is, doctor! Here it finally is. You were right all along.\nSo here we are, standing our watch once again. Awaiting your wise orders.
...Told to? By whom?
The Stone Yard was the last clean district. Now everything is surely lost.
No. We need to find a way to withstand the outbreak now. Perhaps someone will survive.\n"Nothing is over yet. This is just the beginning." This is what I've been told to relay to you.
Death is a lousy employee... and way too willful a partner.
I'll make sure to thank them, whoever they are... as soon as I get there.
We deal in death, Bachelor. We have our own sources. Some of them, on the other side.
...And who is the smart-alec that is so eager to tell me how to live my life?
Dum spiro spero... Latin is as lousy at curing despair as medicine is at curing death.
I'll try that. It's not like I have anything else left to do.
But you are still alive. While there is life, there is hope. I've been told to relay that to you.
Orderly
Oh, you're dead wrong. I will leave this place and I will summon orderlies.
Damn it to hell... You're right... I'm at an impasse.
...Do you have a gun in this house, I wonder? With three bullets?
You must be thinking that you can't leave this place now. But don't let it get to you.
There's only one solution for the infected. Death.
I'm almost curious now. So tell me, what is the answer then?
No. It won't solve anything. The solution is not where you think it is. The answer is not what you think it is.
Oh, you couldn't be more wrong, darling. I'm far from kind.
What makes you think I'm scared? I'm satisfied. I've finally found what I've been looking for.
Indeed. Death may feel horrible, but it's not the end. Fear nothing and be on your way, kind doctor.
Are you trying to convince me that the infected become immortal? Nice try.
Aren't you scared at all...?

You think that if we stay confined in this eggshell, the town will survive? Perhaps it will. Not that you'll have a chance to see it.\nBut if you stay here, with us, you will only find pointless demise. Eternal wait... For now we know that we are immortal.
Siskin
Believer
Perhaps this place gives them more food for thought than the outside.
I didn't come here to indulge in philosophizing, you buffoon. I just did what had to be done.
I'm not wise, just diligent.

Blessed is the dead who thinks he is alive. Why hurt their idyll? That would be too cruel. ...You are a wise man, Bachelor. If they want to live through this evil day again and again... who are we to rob them of their bliss—the chance to take non-existence for existence?
Same here. Curious indeed.
I'm a doctor. I know full well that they don't have much time left. The lad's case in particular doesn't look good... and, honestly, the girl's isn't much better.
I took pity on them. Had a hunch that they'd simply perish here. As for out there, who knows...

You did the right thing, doctor. They left this place while completely assured that they were going to die. To overcome the fear of death is a great achievement. Who knows? Perhaps this particular act of bravery is exactly what saved their lives. I'd be curious to follow their fates. Thank you.
Clockworker
You're exactly who I've been looking for. There are two infected people in that house. Thank heavens, I found them in time. You know what to do.
Firstly, I need a team of orderlies here, stat. Board off the house. Don't let anyone out... myself included. I'm staying in there. I have contracted the disease.
Mikhail Goba, orderly No. 2. Awaiting your command, doctor...
It's plainly obvious.
You have been briefed. You know what to do. Why are you hanging around here?
Burn this pungent nest. The carrier was here, right inside.
If I may... The infection has infiltrated the Stone Yard. The outbreak is gaining momentum.
...No. No. Anything but this. Please tell me you're talking about a revolution, fire, or military coup. Please.
Do you have hearing issues? The one with the unfortunate news is me. There are infected people in this house! Now get on with your duties!
I come bearing unfortunate news, Bachelor...
So I was too late.
...How did it happen?
I'm sorry, Bachelor Dankovsky. The infection has infiltrated the Stone Yard. The outbreak is gaining momentum. \nAwaiting your command.
...How many refugees were there?

A sizable group of refugees from across the river has found its way here tonight. They entered the Stone Yard through the steppe people's camp back behind the Cathedral. That's probably the reason why most of the steppe rabble fled at night. They feared the disease... or maybe your wrath.
...This is it then.
Enough. More importantly, they've gone into hiding all over the place. We won't apprehend them all before dark.
I doubt it.

...Yes. Even if in the end there is but a single living person left, we still need to fight tooth and claw for every life. At least that's how the theory goes. The reality is much ungainlier though...
Now we need to persevere. To stand up to the plague. Perhaps someone will survive.
I think I'm beginning to understand. I believe I have a crucial appointment this evening. I just need to survive until I can attend it.
Not for long.
How does this matter in the slightest now?
But you are still alive.
Seriously? You've breathed new life into me, mate. I'm all aglow.
...Told to? By whom?
The beginning of the end. This town is done for. Yet I will try to make it until the evening to have a word with a certain someone...
"Nothing is over yet. This is just the beginning." This is what I've been told to relay to you.
I'll make sure to thank them, whoever they are... as soon as I get there.
The only competent source of information you have is me. And I regret to inform you that this town is done for.
We deal in death, Bachelor. We have our own sources. Some of them, on the other side.
Oh really?
I've seen them with my own eyes. I know what I'm talking about, mate.
As you wish, sir. But, if I may, you are mistaken.
Orderly No. 2
Tagtaa
I'll do what I can.
We'll see.
He needs to live. Let him suffer. Just not die today.
How can anyone deal with you people and preserve their sanity?! What happened...?
Never seen better...
Everything will be good now. We are grateful to you.
You are an insane, barbaric people! How can you live with yourself?!
So this is what kind of wedding you were celebrating...! Why oh why didn't I listen to the poor wounded guy...
She was a herb bride. Brides join Earth in wedlock, so that others may live.\nIt means no one else will die today. You are the doctor. We did this for you.
Yeah, it's Greek to me...
If only it was so simple. But I doubt that millions of dying people would agree with you.
We fear neither pain nor death. One is immortal while the kin lives.\nYou wouldn't understand.
Are you talking about the plague...? What does it have to do with the earth?
You don't care about your husband's life at all, do you?

If there'd been mourning, the celebration would have been cancelled. If the celebration had been cancelled, the earth would have gone unfed.\nWhen the earth isn't fed, it feeds itself. And that would be far worse. No one would be saved.
You've suffered a great loss. I'm sorry.
Doctors don't always win in their duels with death.
Really? Why?
Well. No one will be saved now...
I'm sorry.
I learned of this place too late.
Mother Boddho gives us no respite. The earth is calling. Such is our fate then.\nFrom the soil we came, and to the soil we return. As for you, go. We need to prepare ourselves.
Herb Bride
Evicted? How? Why?
I suspect you are mistaken. Each household was provided three days' worth of food for the isolation period. The bare minimum. So I very much doubt there are any eatables left anywhere.
People were evicted from three houses yesterday. They must have left food behind. When is it going to be distributed?

And where were the evicted people relocated, I wonder? It's not like there are spare houses in the Stone Yard. When we were trying to accommodate the refugees from across the river, people were packed like sardines. Some of them even had to sleep outside.
Perhaps you're right, there may be food left there. I'll take a look. Which particular houses are you talking about? Who do they belong to?
I don't know. But there may be goods inside, and those houses stand deserted anyway. So why won't they let us in?
I want to take a look personally. Where are these houses? They're guarded, I should hope?
No. It won't happen anytime soon. You'll have to be patient.
I don't know, doctor. The owners are told to have gone back across the river. The whole ordeal's over, isn't it? By the way, does this mean that our own guests will also be evicted soon?
I've forbidden everyone to go outside. Yourself included. But my words seem to fall on deaf ears...
Soldiers, huh... Well, that's reassuring at least. The last thing we need is looting.

I don't know. Rumor has it, there are soldiers standing watch by them. Even if there's no food left inside, perhaps we can at least relocate some refugees there?\nI mean really, doctor! My own house is so packed, there's no room to swing a cat! And you've forbidden them to go outside, too...
Confused Woman
What was the precise wording of the order?
I'm the one giving orders around here.
The building is off limits, doctor. I was ordered not to let anyone in.
Whose brilliant idea was that?
Good. Stand your guard, soldier.
No one is allowed inside. If someone somehow sneaks in, they are to stay in.\nIf anyone doesn't comply, we are allowed to open fire.
Indeed, the instructions were mine. Meaning these orders do not apply to me. Let me in.
There is a back door, huh?

The order follows your own instructions, sir. That's what Captain Longin said: doctor's orders, no exceptions. Full isolation.\nSome hothead sneaked in through the back door this morning... and won't ever return. Whatever he may have stolen, he took to the grave.
Sure, I don't want you to get into trouble. I'll try the other door.
Currying favors, huh? Whatever.

I'm in the Captain's bad books already, doctor. One more slip-up, and he'll do me in, won't even waste time on a court martial.\nThe orders are strict and precise. If you want to try climbing up the window, go ahead. I'll look the other way. But don't ask me to break the chain of command directly. I won't.
Soldier
...What?
How did you get in here? Are you the looter?
You need to look it in the eye. Face to face.
You must be deranged with fear, kind sir. What in the world are you talking about?
Does this house have a second exit?
Bravo. Turns out defeating death is really simple. And here I was, wasting years on this challenge...
Listen. If you can hear it, that means it's close; that means you must muster up your courage and look it in the eye. \nThen it will freeze.... for a while. And you'll get a chance to move forward.
I never have.
Only brave children believe that the monster won't touch them if they hide under the pillow.\nBut that won't save you. Do not deny the obvious. Do not turn your back on it.
Indeed. I'm rather short on the latter.
All right... I'll take a look around.
You don't understand. I was speaking literally. No metaphors.\nFace death. Don't turn your back to it. Find yourself. Waste no time.
"Find myself"? What am I, thirteen?
Don't test my patience. I'm asking you again: is there a way out of here?
You need to find yourself. Then it'll leave you be...
I know that perfectly well...
We're locked in! And I don't think they'll let us out... What shall we do?
To dance with death, you need to face it. Death is a beast of prey. Never turn your back on it.
No it isn't.
Metaphors... You know, I've never been a huge fan of literature.
You won't defeat it. But you can move forward. That is how the world works.
A perfect place for a rehearsal. What happened here?
Go on then. Sorry for interrupting you.
No. I'm an actor. We're having a rehearsal here.
I know. It's called "autosuggestion."
Uh huh. Also I need to do some self-searching. I remember, my straightforward friend.
In's on the walls.\nListen closely. Watch closely. And if you see its face, don't turn away.
Tragedian
Where's everyone?
What's in there?
Inspecting the site, doctor? There's no one here. One civilian got in—and in he stayed. ...He shouted and shouted and shouted and then he didn't.
Why were they evicted in the first place?
No one's reporting that to us. Some people say they've been sent back across the river; other, that they were just relocated to other houses.
Indeed. I'm afraid I've found the thing I was looking for...
Keep your watch and stay alert. Constant vigilance, remember?
Must be something scary inside. Perhaps the tenants found it. Dunno. Hence me asking—are you here to inspect the place?
Soldier
Lockpicks?
Are you all insane? Bloody hell, I never ordered to shoot kids!

Finally you're here, doctor! I just shooed a bunch of children away. They tried to sneak in... I seized lockpicks from them, too. Didn't find the heart to shoot, sir. Forgive me. They're just children, after all.
Hand them over.
Why were the residents of the house evicted?

Well, sir, kids often ferret about empty flats. And the owners of this house were evicted. Here, sir, the two lockpicks I confiscated.\nBut they still got more. They'll never back off... I know what I'm talking about, sir, I was just like that myself.
No, you're not.
Yes. Go.
For some reason... People from the Crucible came by, told them to vacate the premises. I dunno, sir, I was only assigned to this duty this morning.\nAm I dismissed, sir?
Guard
Leaving fingerprints is ill-advised.
Leather Gloves
Protective handwear. The local leatherworks is a less-known branch of Fat Vlad's Bull Project.

Folks here believe that any affliction can be smothered in bandages, and any decently soft cloth can serve as one. Makes one wonder how people with such advanced medical knowledge even get sick at all.
Bandage
Improves health. Stop bleeding, and you stop death—or delay it, at least.

Powders, or "shmowders," as the kids call them, can sometimes cure any disease. Or at least they used to. Khan, the children's leader who now rules the Polyhedron, claims that all the real "shmowders" were used up long before the epidemic.
The box seems to be filled with powder made of assorted ground pills.
Powder

Often used an an offering to the dead, milk serves as a reminder that all that is born must come to an end. It's so popular in the Town that cream separators can be found even in households that seem to have nothing to do with the local Bull Project.
Milk
Warm, creamy. Satisfies hunger and thirst. Often offered to the dead.

The rumor that General Block, the chief commanding officer of the soldiers deployed to the Town, hanged himself on a noose made of tourniquets rather than succumb to the disease, is absurd and unfounded. This rubber band can't support the weight of a grown man.
Tourniquet
Rubber tourniquets are regarded as poor quality by the townsfolk, who prefer the locally made leather ones.

Fresh water is brought to the Town daily from a spring in the steppe and distributed among the households by water bearers. The Gorkhon water has been proven to be clean, but the locals refuse to drink it.
Seemingly sates thirst a bit. Despite the Town standing on the river Gorkhon, fresh drinking water is a rare commodity here.
Water Bottle
A basic protective item that covers the face.
Common among medical personnel, this mask quickly accumulates infection and becomes a hazard itself. It also muffles speech. Still, better than nothing.
Face Mask
A surprising find in autumn, if not useless.
I used to collect these as a kid. Left the collection with my father.
Beetle
One vial can't save the Town—but it can save someone. If only I figure out what it's made of…
"Panacea"
…So Artemy Burakh did manage to make a cure for sand pest after all.
Man needs dreams more than bread... but he still needs the bread.
Bread
Bread is the heart of life. No food is more filling.
Scientifically speaking, there's no consensus on if immunity can be boosted at all. However, these pills work well. According to the box, they were manufactured more than fifty years ago.
Immunity Boosters
Assorted pills of unknown origin. Boost immunity. Smell suspicious.
Secondhand soldier boots, covered in reddish-black stains on the inside. Offer decent protection.
The army was deployed to the Town to reinforce the quarantine measures almost by accident—or so it seems to an outsider. These sturdy boots came with the 4th Division, gaining immediate popularity.
Boots
Orderlies—the volunteer medical assistants—use these costumes borrowed from the local theatre as protective cloaks. This is the traditional costume of the Reaper, an allegory of Death.
Executor Cloak
Protects against infection during contact. The pendants serve no obvious purpose, but tearing them off would be a waste of time.
A warm heart that went out to people. Literally.

In the steppe lore, the center of mind and knowledge is the liver, while the center of feeling and emotion is the lower guts. They view the heart as a less crucial and rather mechanical organ that simply pumps life around, oddly arriving at a consensus with science-based medicine.
Heart
Protective footwear. Helps one rise above their troubles—and the poisoned earth.
Cothurni—unusual footwear that elevates the wearer high above the ground—are popular with the local theatre. It's likely the orderlies owe their awe-inspiring height to them.
Cothurni
Chest of Drawers
Chest
Small Cabinet
Chest
Broken window
Small Cabinet
Cabinet
Cabinet
Small Cabinet
Small Cabinet
Chest of Drawers
Wardrobe
Table
A Focus can be held by an object of any size: a Polyhedron, a room, a nut.
Walnuts
Can be munched down—with little effect. The kids here would sell their souls for a handful.
Nutritious, neat, and well-preserved food that somehow doesn't require a can opener. There's no manufacturer listed on the label, and it's unclear what kind of food is inside.
Canned Food
The can is entirely sealed, so its contents are free of infection. The food itself is quite nutritious.
Healing herbs placed inside the beak overwhelm all other smells. Protects against disease clouds.

The mask of Muu Shubuun, "the wicked bird." Part of the Reaper costume from the local theatre. It doesn't have eyeholes: the mask is mounted above an actor's head, who peeks through a hole in the cloak.
Executor Mask
Peanuts
Can be munched down—with little effect. The kids here would sell their souls for a handful.
A Focus can be held by an object of any size: a Polyhedron, a room, a nut.
It's cold.
