It reflects light at odd angles, making its true size difficult to discern.
Key
Used Bandage
According to sanitary procedures, any object that bears the trace of a deceased person's blood must be burned. According to local belief, it's pointless since the blood will simply appear elsewhere.
Traces of the epidemic are omnipresent.
Package
Contains useful but unknown items. Unfold to extract them.

Long before the current socioeconomic catastrophe, the local townsfolk developed a tradition of barter that the whole community reveled in. This includes many types, such as "tit for tat" and "retrab." It is sometimes secret, with people swapping wrapped items blindly.
Match
Draw the short one!
One must recall that which is most dear to them before the match burns out, or the whole thing won't work.
Spindle
It has almost run out of thread.
More likely to poke your eye out than prick your finger.
Broken Scissors
The Moerae must have been in a hurry—too many threads to cut.

It's said that Clara the Changeling, a thief girl who claims to be a saint, can repair any sharp object just as easily as she cures the sand pest, simply by laying her hands on it. Maybe this is why people refuse to throw away useless junk like broken scissors.
Panacea
A run-of-the-mill medicine vial filled with clotty reddish liquid that smells vaguely of spices. It seems distantly familiar.

Shortly before his tragic demise, Artemy Burakh, a local medicine man, claimed to have produced a miraculous cure capable of eliminating the sand plague completely from one's body. Until now, his claims remained unproven. This may be the only sample in existence.
Raisins
Once juicy berries, now a luxurious treat with a sugary aftertaste.
The locals refuse to eat more than a handful. Perhaps this is because raisins don't spoil, making them a valuable treat in times of famine.
Broke Ampoule
People would use any and all means to cure themselves of the disease.
An ampoule that once contained either life-saving, or life-ending, medicine. It served its purpose—whatever it was—and is now useless.
Lockpick
Twisted and uneven, the local lockpicks require a fast, jabbing motion to unlock a door, else they'll become uncoiled.

It's said that Clara the Changeling, a thief girl who claims to be a saint, can open any door just as easily as she heals the sick, simply by laying her hands on it. Why are her pockets always filled with lockpicks, then?
Toast
Soldier food. There's no reason to prefer it to freshly baked bread.
Letting bread turn stale is frowned upon. Toast arrived to the Town with soldiers' rations and remains undesirable, despite being filling.
Recently stopped, so the original owner has most likely died.
Time doesn't seem to work properly in the Town. There's no other explanation for how Georgiy Kain, the Judge, is twice as young as his twin brother. The Kains' love for clockwork is surely connected.
Pocket Watch
Candle Stub
The stub of a nuptial candle. It smells of earth.
Eva Yan, the mistress of the Stillwater, often burned candles to give her mansion a cozier appearance during the night, less like an observatory.\n\nYet, now it's dark.
Morphine
A person is only alive for as long as they feel pain. Morphine makes you numb to it, seemingly increasing health.

Unsuccessfully banned within the Town by Governor Saburov, in an attempt to alleviate his wife's addiction. Morphine relieves a person of pain, worries, and worldly desires, leaving them drowsy and numb.
Money
Used to buy items in shops. Offering it during common street barter, however, would be taken as offensive.
On the third day of the epidemic, local prices soared. Now, on the eighth day, money has lost all meaning, and people prefer barter instead. It may be inconvenient, but it can be lucrative.
Bull Bell
Bells like this are often hung above graves, in case of lethargy.

The inner surface of this bell is painted with the sigils of the secret, sacred steppe alphabet. It's the knowledge of this alphabet that allowed Artemy Burakh, a local medicine man, to restore his rightful place in the steppe community, shortly before his death.
Fishing Hooks
Sharp objects are regarded as dangerous and thus frowned on by the locals.
While the Gorkhon river has plenty of fish, fishing is unpopular among the locals. Perhaps it has to do with the fact that hooks are sharp objects—heavily frowned upon around here.
Despite the lack of chestnut trees around, chestnuts are everywhere in the Town. Where do they come from?
Chestnut
Can be munched down—with little effect. The kids here would sell their souls for a handful.
Cash Register
Container
Marbles
Children give them names and believe they hold memories, as though they are alive.
No one knows how marbles appear in the Town. No one makes or delivers them. They simply pop up here and there; on the floor, under the pillow, or right on the ground.
The Bahelor
The sand plague has infiltrated the town. The source or carrier has to be around. Where?
The source or carrier do not matter. What matters is finding the way to beat the disease. How can it be done?
It's not the plague I'm fighting. The plague is but a guise. Who is my true foe?
A patient is waiting for an examination here. Flat 3.\nIs it the sand pest...?
The orderlies are having a celebration.
The shop
The local Cathedral served as a refuge for the people who exhibited suspicious signs
The steppe people are preparing for a funeral
The drugstore
Here, an odd house piqued children's curiosity. Something feels off.
The Crucible. Judge Georgiy Kain lives here
The anti-epidemic committee. The place to take day-to-day concerns to.
"The Stillwater. Uninhabited due to its owner's suicide.\nDoes the house mourn her passing?"
An odd woman, possible quack, who is told to have found the cure for the plague, lives here
The local actors are staging a mime play in front of the Cathedral
The town's attention seems to be directed here
Deceased Man
[The man is dead.]
[Doesn't seem like the sand pest, but there's no harm in double-checking. Better safe than sorry.]
Nothing for a doctor to do here. Call gravediggers.
I'm sorry, lad. You are coming with me. I'll take care of you.
[The symptoms do not fit the horrible disease that's exterminated two thirds of the town's population in a week.\nJudging by the preliminary analysis, the man died of a massive stroke.]
I still think we should perform an autopsy. I'll call the orderlies, they'll take the body where it belongs.
Your father didn't die of the sand plague. False alarm... he had a stroke.
This is it, doctor. You fought valiantly, but you've lost. A foe like me is no match for men, and you are no exception. \nSo, are you ready to die?
No. That is not what I intend to do.
Yes. I'm ready.
Good. Finally you understand. I really hope that you do—for your own sake; otherwise, this is where it all ends.
Who knows...
Not for me.
Most people would simply cease to be at this point. Few would make a step beyond. Let's see who you are. Give me your hand.
Here it is.
Let's see.
That's enough. I don't care.
So you didn't understand anything... Stubborn man. \nYou've done more than is humanly possible. You've cordoned off the safe part of the town. But it was all in vain. I'm here already.
I don't believe you. This is all a dream. A nightmare.

A prophetic dream, Bachelor. Such is the nature of the plague. \nThe town seems clean and calm in the morning. But somewhere in the depths of a nondescript house a carrier is already lurking. Come noon, fleas appear in hordes, transmitting the sickness. So do rats. By the evening, the whole town is in agony. You've seen this many times already. \nSo, are you ready to die?
No. Don't even try. Soon I'll wake up, and you'll be gone.
If what you're saying is true... then yes, I am.

No. You may not see me at once, but that doesn't mean I won't be there. I'm telling you, I'm already in this part of the town. Please understand that resistance is pointless. You need to come to terms with my existence and accept me, like you accept the law of gravity. I am earth. We are of the same nature. Are you ready to die, Bachelor?
No. Fighting death is my job.
Well... Praemonitus praemunitus. If you've infiltrated the Stone Yard already, all I need to do is find you.
You've been studying death all your life, yet the understanding of its nature still eludes you. Like a child, you're squeezing your eyes shut to hide from the monster.
No, I'm not. If you are truly already here, then hide all you want. Here I come.
As you wish. In that case, go and see for yourself.
Begone, Plague. Out of my way.
The sand plague has infiltrated the Town. The source, or the carrier, must be around. Where?
The source, or the carrier, does not matter. What matters is discovering how to defeat the disease. How can it be done?
This is not a fight against the plague. The plague is only a facade. Who is my true foe?
Most orderlies have abandoned the Stone Yard. Few remain on duty.
Someone's spreading a rumor that I'm dead.
The orderlies have registered me as among the deceased. Someone will pay for this sick joke.
The Judge paid me a visit this night while I was still asleep.
Georgiy Kain is lifting the quarantine.
The Judge is seemingly the only person around who doesn't believe that the outbreak has been curbed.
The Judge claims that death is not the end, but rather a test waiting to be passed by every person.
A suspicious crowd has gathered by one of the houses in the Dusk district.
The suspicious visitors of a house in the Dusk district claim that they've come to see a dream-teller.
According to the dream-teller, death can be proper or improper. She promised to teach me how to die right.
When one dies properly, they are greeted by something other than non-existence beyond the threshold. But how does one die properly?
I cannot die right now. Whatever waits for me on the other side, I simply cannot afford to take risks.
A boy named Sticky implores me to not give nuts to a girl named Shrew, not under any circumstances.
Sticky would go as far as to buy nuts from me, trading them for useful items like bandages.
A girl named Shrew claims I promised to bring her nuts a while ago.
Shrew would trade nuts for lockpicks, which are the only way to get inside a suspicious house.
I traded nuts to Sticky.
I traded nuts to Shrew.
According to Shrew, I'm delirious, hallucinating yesterday's events… and not for the first time. The kind girl wants my misery to end.
According to Shrew, I'm delirious, hallucinating yesterday's events… and not for the first time. My young friend plays doctor, not wanting me to abandon the game.
The tragedians believe that I have no heart.
I have a heart now. Perhaps the tragedians would like to have a look.
I misinterpreted the tragedians.
A terrible appointment awaits me this evening. No matter what, one shouldn't play by the rules, not even the rules of this very game.
There is a sick person in Neck, 1.
Not the plague. The man has died of a stroke.
The local Cathedral served as a refuge for those who showed suspicious signs.
I cannot diagnose the couple in the Cathedral.
Not all odonghs have left for the steppe.
An odongh is on the brink of death. But he can't be operated on without supplies.
The Hippocratic oath was observed, but it wasn't plague.
The steppe creature hasn't survived the operation. In any case, it wasn't plague.
Behind the locked doors of one house in the Dusk district, one can hear footsteps.
I've found infected people.
The town is doomed. My search was pointless.
I've found the infected people… but what does it matter? The Stone Yard is doomed. Was searching for the carrier even my true mission here…?
Most orderlies have abandoned the Stone Yard. Few remain on duty.
Someone's spreading a rumor that I'm dead.
The Judge paid me a visit this night while I was still asleep.
Georgiy Kain is lifting the quarantine.
The tragedians believe that I have no heart.
I have a heart now. Perhaps the tragedians would like to have a look.
I misinterpreted the tragedians.
The tragedians believe that I have no heart.
I have a heart now. Perhaps the tragedians would like to have a look.
I misinterpreted the tragedians.
A suspicious crowd has gathered by one of the houses in the Dusk district.
The suspicious visitors of a house in the Dusk district claim that they've come to see a dream-teller.
According to the dream-teller, death can be proper or improper. She promised to teach me how to die right.
A suspicious crowd has gathered by one of the houses in the Dusk district.
The suspicious visitors of a house in the Dusk district claim that they've come to see a dream-teller.
According to the dream-teller, death can be proper or improper. She promised to teach me how to die properly.
A boy called Sticky implores me not to give nuts to a girl called Shrew under any circumstances.
Sticky would even buy nuts from me, trading for useful items like bandages.
A girl called Shrew claims that I promised to bring her nuts a while ago.
Shrew would trade nuts for lockpicks, which are the only way to get inside the suspicious house.
There is a sick person in Neck, 1.
Not the plague. The man died of a stroke.
The local Cathedral served as a refuge for the people who exhibited suspicious signs.
I cannot diagnose the couple in the Cathedral.
Not all odonghs have left for the steppe.
An odongh is on the brink of death. But he can't be operated on, not without supplies.
The Hippocratic oath was observed, but it wasn't plague.
The steppe creature hasn't survived the operation. In any case, it wasn't plague.
Not all odonghs have left for the steppe.
An odongh is on the brink of death. But he can't be operated on without supplies.
The Hippocratic Oath was observed, but it wasn't plague.
The steppe creature hasn't survived the operation. In any case, it wasn't plague.
One can hear footsteps from behind the locked doors of one of the houses in the Dusk district.
I've found infected people.
The town is doomed. My search was pointless.
I've found infected people.
One can hear footsteps from behind the locked doors of one of the houses in the Dusk district.
I've found infected people.
The Town is doomed. My search was pointless.
What were you dreaming about anyway? You were screaming as though devils were dragging you to hell by hooks...
Something like that, actually. Could you remind me where the sick man is?
I dreamed that the plague has infiltrated this place, the Stone Yard. It talked to me and said, "Here I am. The birds are gathering around the marble nest." Whatever that means...
Death talked to me. It said I only have time until the evening.
I see... Were there bulls in your dream?
...How do you know?
Just one. Rather spine-chilling though. Why do you ask?
Too bad. If you dream of a bull, that means the dream is prophetic. So it'll come true. Everybody knows this omen.\nYou need to see Sahba.
I don't believe in omens. Now please remind me where I'm supposed to go.
Well, that probably means a lot of important things are going to happen today. And with your kind help, my "today" started rather early... too early, perhaps.

You need to go to Blacky—to the left, through the gate. His house will be the one directly in front of you. As for the Crucible, it's on the main square, and that's where the Judge lives. He's probably at home.
I've been in this town for a week now, I know where the Crucible is. It's hard to miss the main square.
All right. As for you, stay in!
Uh huh. Oh, and one more thing... Don't give nuts to Shrew.
Shrews are the least of my concerns now, lad. Rats, on the other hand...
Why? I thought rodents liked nuts.
Because. Just don't.
I'll consider it.
You are late. A man died.\nAllow me to draw your attention to the fact that people keep dying because of you. Sometimes I suspect that death is not a foe of yours, but rather a partner.
...How did he die?
Really? What are you doing here then?
Mind how you're addressing your superior, orderly. State your name, number, and assigned duty.
I'm just standing my watch.\nCome, little birds, and gather around the marble nest!
If the body's already been taken away, why are you still here?
Why do I have to keep reminding you orderlies of what exactly your responsibilities are?

Ah, so you think I'm an orderly? Yeah, these costumes do have their downsides. Not the best outfits if you want to talk to someone fact to face. The person inside would find it difficult to prove their identity...
Who are you?
That doesn't excuse you from being polite. Especially when talking to me.
This man died of your negligence.
What...?
You're lying.

Neither pox nor cholera nor sand pest kill people. All they do is reduce their lifetime. Yet the time of the world is yours to control.\nWho was the murderer: a sickness that let no second go to waste—or you, who bothered not to hurry? I think it's the latter.
Get lost, whoever you are. I don't want to see you ever again.
It's all right. It's all right. There is still a chance to fix everything.
Relieved? An ordinary stroke... Yes, not everyone dies of the sand pest.\nOh no, it all begins someplace else. You've got the wrong address.
Well, perhaps you could tell me the correct one?
What are you doing here?
Where is the boy? Where did you come from? ...Report your name, number, and assigned duty. Now.
Just standing my watch. Birdies, birdies, gather here around the marble nest!
If you came for the body, where are your assistants?
Why do I have to keep reminding you orderlies of what exactly your responsibilities are?

Ah, so you think I'm an orderly? Yeah, these costumes do have their downsides. Not the best outfits if you want to talk to someone fact to face. The person inside would find it difficult to prove their identity...
Who are you then?
That doesn't excuse you from being polite. Especially when talking to me.

Oh, you thought you could catch me on the first try? That's quite an ego, doctor. Ambition seems to be your middle name.\nYou challenge death—and expect your fight to be this simple? You must be kidding... I'm almost offended.
I've been fighting death for many years. And I usually succeed.
Stop following me!

You are arrogant and condescending, doctor. You despise people. Their life, health, and time mean nothing to you.\nWant an example? You turned the Cathedral into an isolation ward, and now it is chock-full of exhausted and terrified people. They've spent a torturous night there, waiting for you to examine them... yet you're in no hurry to relieve their suffering.
Everyone who exhibited suspicious signs was brought there. It had to be done.
God damn it! Slipped my mind completely...
Who were you talking to just now, doc?
Is this your idea of a joke?
You tell me. I couldn't make heads or tails of what you were saying.
To you. And I've got more to say. I know who you are.
No, sir. I was ordered to come, sir. A person has died here, sir.\nWe take our orders seriously around here, sir.
Forget it. Doesn't matter... Just do your job.
Drop the act. I know it was you.
I just came in here, doc.
You're lying.
Who the hell are you?

I'm an orderly, doctor. Avrely Gubar, number eleven.\nThese outfits, sir, make it hard to tell which one of us is which, but we're wearing them on your orders, sir... And they do help, thank you kindly. Good protection.
Well, you're good at changing voice, I'll give you that...

...Are you feeling okay, doctor, sir? You're kind of pale, dark rings under the eyes present, too...\nYou must be overworked and exhausted. Your schedule is insane. You need to have a good long sleep, sir. Very long.
It's all right... I'll have a nice long sleep in the evening.
You are correct, I am overworked.
There's no time to rest. I'm planning to examine this whole house. Do you have a master key?
I do, sir. Here it is, sir. Please kindly note how fragile it is, sir, only good to unlock a couple of doors, three maybe. Then it breaks.
Better than nothing. Hand it over.
Take care of the deceased.
Orderly No. 11
...Can you hear them?
What?
The voices.
That must be in the mansion.
No... nothing. Must have been leaves.
Why did you come here? Your camp is in the steppe, behind the Cathedral.
I used to live in this house, you know. That's where I stayed when I came to your town a week ago...
It's too sorrowful there. One of us is getting married. No time for joy.
I'm sorry.
Isn't marriage a happy occasion?
Yes, your people's rituals are monstrous.
Not according to our traditions.
It'd be curious to see your funeral then.
At Eva Yan's, I know. And then she died. Do you know why?
I do. Because of me.
Well, she didn't succumb to the sand pest...
She commited suicide. Jumped from atop your bloody Cathedral.
You're mistaken. Eva is alive.
Whatever they say, don't believe them. Whatever it feels like, don't worry.\nYou're alive.
I know.
So are you.
So scary... But... Just... Keep yourself together, all right, doc? The fight is not over, is it?\n...Is it?
I think it is.
Of course it isn't. Don't worry.
You can stay here for as long as you like. The world is your oyster. You can even live forever if you want. As for the banging... and the other horrors... just forget them.
How can anyone forget all this?

Just keep it out of your head. Allow yourself to zone out. And morning will come once again. Once again, I will... erm... wake you up, sort of. Will help you, too, like I always do.\nEverything will be fine, like it was before. Eh?
Sounds tempting, can't argue with that.
How about shutting it for a second, so as not to break my concentration? That would be of immense help.
Staff Sergeant Plover. Contrary to the instructions of a representative of the local authorities, Judge Georgiy Kain, I kept my squad on security duty. Your orders, sir?
Tell me more. What happened?
Yesterday, the Cathedral was filled to the brim with people who exhibited signs of the sand plague. I hope they're all still inside?
Where is the Judge?

Well... There were forty or so potentially infected people inside. Then, yesterday they told us the outbreak had been curbed. No additional protective measures necessary. The locals even went as far as to try and break the people out of the Cathedral, "else they would languish in vain." The judge cancelled the quarantine. Now everyone's gone.
Why are you still here then?
Where is the Judge?
Gone to his place. There, up the stairs; go towards that beakheaded buffoon of yours and you won't miss it.
In that case, I'll go and have a word with him.
He's not a buffoon. It's a protective outfit. Anyway, why haven't you left?
I don't want to be court-martialled. It wasn't the Judge who assigned us here. \n...And it's frightening too, doctor. One can't be too cautious.
Scared? Of what?
A couple of them stayed inside. The rest have scattered, but these ones... Must be "mites", plaguebearers. Either dead on their feet or responsible enough not to flee. We haven't checked.
You don't need to. I'll do it.
You have my gratitude, Sergeant. It's a relief to see that at least one person still has a head on their shoulders.
Are you kidding? Gone with the wind.
Why are you still here then?
Well, doctor? Is this it?
I don't think so. But let them stay inside. That's what they want anyway.
I don't know. I'm not sure. I'd rather not take risks.
I think it might be.
Any further orders, sir?
Lock up the Cathedral from the outside. Then you may go.
At ease. Do whatever you want.
Stay here and keep an eye on these two. The threat is real.
So, that's it, right? ...We're free to go?
Why are there so few of you? Where are the rest of the guards? I left two platoons here!
Are you the commanding officer?
What's going on?
I mean, the Cathedral's been opened again, so... Everyone's gone. Ours is the only unit left. Plover is a beast when it comes to discipline and orders.
Inside, there were three dozens of people whose symptoms resembled those of the sand plague! What's going on...?
Unlocked? By whom?
Look over there, by the entrance, see? That's Staff Sergeant Plover. Ask him. He's the one who talked to the people in charge.
Until the outbreak has been curbed, I'm the person in charge!
I mean, they say the threat is no more... only across the river, but the plague is dying out there too. We managed a counterattack on it, didn't we?
What counterattack, soldier? Infection isn't human, you can't shoot it!
...At ease.

We're guarding them "wicks." As per your orders. The moment anyone so much as sneezes, they're dragged here.\nOver the last three days, all kinds of people were run to earth and brought here... Today, all of them were let go.
What do you mean, "let go"? By whom?
I know I'm sick. So I'm going to surrender myself to the soldiers. Let them execute me.\nIt's as simple as leaving the Cathedral, you know.
Is that so? Well, why are you still here then?
How long have you been here?
Extend your arm please, I'd like to check the pulse. And look me in the eye.
Your stubbornness will be your undoing... and your main regret. You'll find yourself in our shoes sooner than you think.
My shoes are not that comfortable either. Not the type to get jealous about.
Right. I'll be sure to remember your keen warning.
Dora over there holds me back. Talk to her, doctor. Examine her and if she's fine—let her go.
And if she's not...?
So you want the easy way out, huh? Dying is easy. Living is hard and painful.

Then the bullet is, once again, preferable. Faster, anyway. I've seen the victims of the sand plague.\nIf she has already contracted it, just help me convince her that she must walk out of this place and face death with an unwavering heart. She'll take your word.
Aren't you afraid of death?
Stop it.

You have to be a moron to not be afraid of death. But death at least promises some semblance of hope. Here, no hope is fathomable.\nI don't want to spend my time imprisoned in this stone sack. Firstly, it's boring. Secondly, it hurts. I'm feverish.
Isn't it the other way round? Dum spiro spero. While you're alive, there is still hope, yet death is final.
...And delirious. You are indeed in a bad condition. Let us begin with the examination.
Take a look around. This isn't life.
Let's get this discussion over with and move on to the examination. Please extend your arm.

[The symptoms do remind you of the sand plague: fever, dilated pupils, slurred speech patterns. He will not live to see this evening. But a person sick with sand plague at this stage would also have yellowish skin coloration. It's hard to say for sure.]
I'm sorry, but I can't just let you die. If you're infected, I need to keep you here as proof that I'm right about the new outbreak. I'm locking you in.
...Say what you will, but it's not the sand pest. I'd say euthanasia by soldiers' bullets is inadvisable in your case. You will be escorted to my place. I'll take another look at you in the evening.
I'm not going anywhere without her.
Touching. In that case, wait here. I'll examine your friend.
Sure, the two of you may go. I don't need to examine her, the case is clear.\nThis isn't it...
Go with her then. Your friend is fine.
Your choice. That means the both of you are staying.
Dora wouldn't leave without me. You have to find a way to trick her. Tell her I'm okay.\nShe doesn't belong here.
...To hell with you two. Get lost, both of you.\nI hope I won't come to regret this decision.
Her choice. That means you both are staying.
To hell with me—but have pity on her! She wouldn't go without me!
...All right. Get lost. I really hope this will serve as a good reference when I pass to kingdom come.
No. This is my final answer.
For all eternity, it feels. I'm tired of this torture. I'd prefer death. I want out.
Go then, what are you waiting for?
...You'd prefer death? Seriously?
Get a grip! Now is not the time to be afraid.
I'm not afraid.
You be the change you want to see in the world.
You are a doctor. Your job is to preserve people's lives. You hear me? You—are—life!\nWhile you're with us, there is still hope. For as long as you live, so do we!
I know. Shut your face.
Your logic is very much flawed, but I got the gist.
So now you're fervently clinging to life? That's quite a vivid contrast... you looked way more dignified back in the Cathedral.
You're back. So it's true? That you're losing your grip and giving up?
Why, you seem to have abandoned your suicidal fantasies! Looking good and oddly healthy, my mate.
Well, my hands get awfully tired, what with them being constantly raised up in the air, so forgive me if my grip is a bit slack.
Spare me your sense of humor, Bachelor. You didn't answer my question. Are you throwing in the towel?\nOr perhaps a more flattering wording will do it. Did you choose to surrender?
Who told you this nonsense?
No. I'm prepared to fight to the end.
It's not a surrender... but rather a triumph of common sense.
That orderly, an assistant of yours.
I wonder what he meant.
It wasn't an orderly.
Don't listen to him, he's raving. Thinks he's got sand pest. But I know perfectly well it's mere consumption...
Is that so? I didn't know you were a doctor too. Any suggestions in terms of treatment, dear colleague?
And you are his... who?
I'd rather examine you. Your arm, if you please... and look at the light.
Outside spells death. Yet in here, we can live on.
...For a while.
I'd rather say outside spells a significant degree of uncertainty.
...Sister. Of a sort. Why should you care? How is it important?
What is important then?
Indeed. I'd rather examine your own condition. Look at the light, please, and don't inhale too deeply.
For as long as we're here, we remain alive. This is what matters. Just... just leave us be, I suppose. Lock us in, if that's what safety demands. All I want is to stay with him some more.
...And now let me feel your forehead, please.
Your friend doesn't seem to share your views.

[She's unnaturally pale and drowning in sweat, but you see no other signs of the sand plague. The vacant look and generally unfocussed appearance betray a commotion of the nerves that surpasses general anxiety.]
I see no obvious signs of infection. But have it your way—I'd rather you stayed here. That would be for the better.
I don't know... Hard to say for sure. Whatever, you may go.
For the better indeed. For both of us.
The Cathedral is going to be locked. Farewell.
...But not for me. I do have a conscience, after all. On second thought, I suppose it would be better to relocate you two to my place to keep an eye on you.
Don't! Leaving this place spells doom...
What makes you so sure anyway? Perhaps it doesn't. You two will go to my place and stay supervised. End of story.
What makes you say that? Your chances don't look that bad. As for your friend, give me a moment to examine him...
No. You are going to my place. The Neck district, 3, if I recall correctly. The best chance you two have is under my supervision.
For your friend. But not for you.
For everyone. You, too. And the poor souls that have abandoned this place!
Well, suit yourself then. You two are free to stay here if you want.
That's a fair point... Well. You know what? I'd like you two to go to my place and stay there. I want to reexamine you in the evening.
He's raving. He has a fever.
I know. Now I'd like to examine you, please.
If he stays here, he won't make it to the evening.
He will. For as long as we're here, there is no death.
"Death is nothing to us. When we exist, death is not; and when death exists, we are not..." That's quite enough. Extend your hand, please.

It's all right. I'll just pay it no heed. It's just a transition, right? And transitions are always uncomfortable and arduous.\nBut it's all right. See, doctor? I'm not afraid. I keep on working. Am I doing good...?
Working? What are you talking about?
Yes, Dora, you're doing very good. I'm proud of you.
You are a very brave girl. I can't say the same for myself. Forget it all and prepare to die. I think this is it.
I'm tending to the sick. They're so scared, so hungry for consolation...
I can see you're counting me among them. Thank you kindly.
All right. Keep on working. Not for their sake, but for your own.
You are a very kind girl, Dora. I can't say the same for myself. Forget it all and prepare to die. I think this is it.
I'm so happy we left the Cathedral behind. Thank you, doctor.\nIf not for you, I'd never take such risk. And I wouldn't let my brother do it too.
Your condition has plainly improved... which is odd. I was certain you wouldn't make it until the evening. What happened?
I'm happy for you too. The Cathedral gave me the impression of a rather dull and desolate place.
I'd call it neither dull nor desolate—there's much more to it than meets the eye. But this place is even more fascinating.
Yeah... never a dull moment in these parts.
Really? As for me, I'd skip this town at the earliest opportunity... but the railway station was closed as soon as the epidemic broke out.
I feel so strange. I have new eyes now; new hands. I want to live! I want to work. To be helpful.
Lovely. In that case, you could see to the visitors of this place. People come here from time to time... and soon there'll be more of them.
Strange indeed. I'd examine you more thoroughly if I had the time.
Well, perhaps this miraculous Cathedral of yours wasn't preserving your lives, but rather doing the opposite? Have you considered that?
Young crops will rise soon. Stone flowers.
You are a creature of the steppe. Your camp is back behind the Cathedral. Go back to your lot...
You're a herb gatherer, aren't you? You odonghs have a special way with grass and herbs, I know that. Are you expecting a ripe harvest here?
Special harvest. Marble flowers. Granite flowers.\nEarth is breathing. Ripe harvest on its way.
Don't you have enough herbs in the steppe? Go back where you belong.
If anyone sees you, there's bound to be trouble. As far as I know, the locals aren't too fond of your kind.
The air is changing. Hear it. The smell is changing. Touch it.\nSomething bad is brewing. Right here.
Do you feel something odd? What is it?
Are you by any chance... out of it? Delirious, perhaps? I can't make out what you're saying.
Look closely. Listen closely. Where are the flies flying? Where are the rats rattling?\nWhere is new life germinating? Soon, it begins.
I hate fearmongers, you know.
Then take your stone grass with you and get lost.
Hello, doctor. What did you dream of today?
I don't believe in dream-telling. What I do believe is that your place is across the river. You have five minutes to pack your belongings.
Who are you?

I dreamed... I dreamed that an outbreak would happen here today. The plague itself came to me wearing an orderly's outfit and gave me time until the evening... No matter. It sounds stupid when I say it out loud.
Why, doctor? What have I done to you? I thought all the healthy people belonged here, to this part of the town. And yet you would banish me from this ark...
There are alarming rumors circulating, and they have to do with you. People claim that you supposedly can cure the sand plague.
If the desperate infected people find out you're here, they'll storm the place... and succeed.
If you can truly cure the sand plague, you'll manage.

You wouldn't even say hello, huh... I'm Sahba. The townsfolk like you call me Aspity. My real, steppe name is Sahba-ötün, but it's hard to pronounce. I am a souvilag'sh by trade. Meaning... "the one who teaches how to walk". It's untranslatable to your language.
Nope, very much translatable. So what is a teacher like you doing here?
I'm not one of the townsfolk. I'm an outsider.

I need a dreamhook. Try to remember the mood, if only for a second. This is crucial.\nThen, in your mind's eye, imagine a single detail that seemed pivotal to you. Just don't try to invent anything new; remember it. Then I'll be able to see your dream as if it was mine.
I confronted death... like I always do. It asked me if I was ready to die.
I remember you! You were there, in my dream, telling me I failed to understand something.
The sand plague infiltrated the Stone Yard. Looked very realistic, too...
Stop playing games with me! Pack up your things and leave. This whole steppe mysticism shtick is getting on my nerves.

You're missing the point, doctor. And I think you also tend to mix up death and plague, which are actually not the same. You mix up death, death, and death. But they are not the same. You can't even tell death from death. Not the same. How many different words did I use?
Forty-something, all of them meaningless.
One. Are you telling me they sounded different to you?
The thing that came to you tonight was death—not death, as you thought. It wants you to understand why it haunts you, and it won't take you in until you do. It's as simple as that.
I see. So was I supposed to just accept everything and meekly go belly up?

No. If you agree to die without understanding, you will simply cease to exist.\nI doubt that that would be of interest to you... and it'd definitely be pointless to your visitor. And it would never do anything unless it has a point.
Death literally is the cessation of existence. I've been studying it all my life. I know what I'm talking about.

...This is precisely why it can't just take you in. You're blind; you don't know the first thing about it. Death is not the end... not at all.\nWould you like me to prove it to you? You're a doctor, you'd easily see through any act. Watch me die properly. When it knocks, simply open the door.
All right, let's take a look at your proof.
Why would I be convinced by your gimmicks? It's not like you have a degree.
Like hell I will. Find yourself someone more gullible.
Because I know how to die properly. Do you have a weapon?
No, I don't.
Yes, it's called intelligence. And now it's telling me that you're spewing nonsense. End of story.
Fine. Let's see your proof.

Not true. I simply know how to die properly. This made people think I'm immortal... which I'm not. Then they began gossiping about how I can't get infected, how I'm invulnerable... which I'm, once again, not. Then they invented some kind of non-existent cure... This is all nonsense.
That doesn't change the fact that your presence jeopardizes the district. The last thing I need is for insane plaguebearers to gather here.
Actually, I came here because I was waiting for you. I can leave, fine. But don't you have a very unpleasant appointment scheduled for today's evening? Are you sure you're prepared for it?
How do you know? Can you read minds or something?
Yes I am. Now off with you.
See? There's nothing terrible about it. I died properly.
Hm... Care to do an encore? Slowly, please.
What do you mean, properly?
...This is a rather torturous experience, Bachelor. Very much so, to be honest.
So why did you do it then?

I knew why it needed to happen. Never let this understanding slip my mind, not even for a second.\n...Of course, concentrating and the ability to clear your mind of any secondary thoughts are crucial. That's all there's to it.
And why did it need to happen?
This time I did it because I needed to convince you that running away from death will get you nowhere. You won't win this way, you'll only make it worse.
How is it worse if death is painful? What's wrong with postponing the experience?

It makes you gradually more and more frightened. It won't help you understand how to die properly. You will still die in the end... with fits and starts.\nAnd that, Bachelor, will be your true, absolute end. You will simply cease to be. It's not quite as unpleasant as eternal damnation, but still rather less than thrilling.
All right. I need to think this whole situation over.
No, I still don't believe you. This is all some kind of trick. I've seen the performance of a world-class magician in the capital, his spiel was roughly the same.
"Drop your weapon, stop the resistance, unlock the gate, and we will spare your lives." The oldest trick in the book, yet it never fails.

You are far from cowardly, doctor. But your mulishness rivals that of a bull. Your head is stuffed with science; your eyes, sewn shut.\nYou will walk this path time and again, until every last bit of your resolve wears off. And who needs you without it?
I don't like being manipulated. Your sermons fell on deaf ears here.
Who is behind that door?
Death, obviously.
It's nice to see that it's so well-mannered as to knock.
Well, luckily for us, it's still locked out. As for you, your place is across the river.
Good job, scientist. You did it. Was it hard to cope with fear?
Fear? Surely you wanted to say "curiosity"? A bit, yes.
Not in the slightest.
Stop showing off. You've a master at giving the creeps, I admit.
What about thoughts?
Not thinking about a polar bear? You can imagine how well that went.
I like neither overactive imaginations nor superstitions, scientist. I like facts. Here's one: the thing that was behind your back is not standing there anymore. You're free. You've won.
...What do you mean?
I don't believe you. It was an impressive miracle-play, granted, but how can you call me a winner when the outbreak across the river has not gone anywhere?

Easily. Watch me: you're a winner. Any moron can save lives, and everyone wants to. Refusing to open the door to an enemy though... so fierce, so alluring, so personal, made just for you!\nStop arguing, scientist. You've won.
Arguing with you is more trouble than it's worth. Please allow the winner to indulge in the lowly pleasure of saving lives. You said you know someone who's not affected by the sand pest...?
Any chance I've become immune to the disease now, like those... how'd-you-call-thems of yours?
My faithful are immune to the disease. I can bring one to your place if you want. You'll have a look at him. The winner is allowed to...
The things I do for science.
Please bring me one, yes.
Yes, Sahba. Please bring me one.
Yes, Aspity. Please bring me one.

The thing that was behind your back is not standing there anymore.\nYou were its only purpose, after all. You were the one longing so badly for an unbeatable for to fight. So it came, but—in a twist—you didn't open. Offended, it went away...
Ha ha. Very bloody funny.
Don't you ever say that again. Not even as a joke. The mere thought of me being "the only purpose" of the whole outbreak, of the town perishing...

...You are far from cowardly, doctor. Mulish though. Your head is stuffed with science; your eyes, sewn shut.\nYou will walk this path time and again, until every last bit of your resolve wears off. And who are you without it? Who would need you?
I don't like being manipulated. Your sermons fell on deaf ears here.
Who is behind that door?
Death, obviously.
It's nice to see that it's so well-mannered as to knock.
Well, luckily for us, it's still locked out. As for you, your place is across the river.
See? There's nothing terrible about it. I died properly.
Hm... Care to do an encore? Slowly, please.
What do you mean, properly?
...This is a rather torturous experience, Bachelor. Very much so, to be honest.
So why did you do it then?

I knew why it needed to happen. Never let this understanding slip my mind, not even for a second.\nConcentration and the ability to clear your mind of any secondary thoughts are crucial. That's all there's to it.
And why did it need to happen?

This time I did it because I needed to convince you that running away from death will get you nowhere. You won't win this way, you'll only make it worse.\n...There's no need to hurry, though. Suicide only leads to void. It's not the right way to cross the threshold.
How can it be worse? And if death is so painful, why hurry?

Because there is fear swelling inside you. And fear won't help you understand how to die properly.\nEven without the understanding, you will still die, Bachelor, but it won't be a true death. To the contrary; it will be your complete, absolute end. You will simply cease to be. It's not quite as unpleasant as eternal damnation, but still rather less than thrilling.
All right. I need to mull this whole situation over.
No, I still don't believe you. This is all some kind of trick. I've seen the performance of a world-class magician in the Capital, his spiel was roughly the same.
"Drop your weapons, stop resisting, unlock the gate, and we will spare your lives." The oldest trick in the book, yet it never fails.
Diseased
Ouzel
Crow
Goose
Pigeon
Nightjar
Goose
Starling
Starling
Oriole
Oriole
Dove
Dove
Ouzel
Crow

…As for the relationship with nature, we are rebelling against it! No wonder it pushes back. The steppe people live as though they're in a primeval time reverse, like stone axes have yet to be invented. Worshipping bulls! Talking to herbs! They don't even have a real language, it's all bol bol this and gur gur that! And yet for some reason, we allow them here.
And what's wrong with that? There are many peoples on earth untouched by civilization.
But they do have a language, and a rather beautiful one at that.

What about the sacrifices? I'll have you know they still make those. It's simply wrong to entangle different ages within the same space, is all! Their age is different. Our time is broken! It's crippled, Bachelor! They've come from the past. So release them, let them return to the earth they hold so dear. Let them leave.
Is someone holding them here?
Make sacrifices? You're exaggerating, pal. I find it hard to believe.
Oh yes, the sacrifices. Please send a soldier squadron to the camp behind the Cathedral. I want it burnt to ashes.
Sacrifices… This is a nuptial ceremony of theirs. And they have a point…

Someone is… our rulers. They have embedded the steppe people into this town, carved them into its warm flesh. This isn't a town, it's an honest-to-God minotaur. A chimera. And chimeras have remarkably short lifespans and bad health. Can you breed a snake and a crane? You can, yes. But the progeny won't live long.
A chimera, huh? You make a good point.
…You have no idea how far interbreeding can go. I know a thing or two about living organisms, so take my word for it.
Have you ever seen a mule?

This is an impossible town, Bachelor! You just can't have your cake and eat it. Can't mix oil and water. Can't connect similarly-charged magnet poles… or rather you can, but only by force. And as soon as that force falters, it's all going to be shredded to pieces. We are abusing nature!
You need a sociologist, not a medical scientist. I'm not sure if biological principles are applicable here.
If not for the rebellion against nature, we still wouldn't be able to use fire.

Doctor, would you mind settling an argument of ours? You are, after all, an outsider in this town, with a clear head and a fresh outlook. We've been arguing over the reasons for the sand plague outbreak. You would, of course, agree that it happened in this particular town for a reason, wouldn't you?
Indeed. I don't believe in random chance.
It could have happened anywhere.

Exactly, Bachelor. Not a single alarm. Nothing suspicious. All thanks to your iron will and the strict measures you enforced. The disease has remained across the river. Here, it's all clear. Anyone who felt weak or unwell was led to the Cathedral, but it's obvious that none of them were infected. So, will you settle our argument…?
All right, I'm all ears.
I couldn't care less for your arguments. Get back to work!

As a matter of fact, this town is nothing but a machine… produced to challenge the limits of human potential. And our ideas of how people connect to each other. Our very relationship with nature. For more than a century, the three families ruling us have been running such experiments on the local population. You've found yourself in a utopia.
Death is a limit, unjustly imposed upon men. Humanity has long outgrown it. So what exactly were you arguing about?
Don't you have better things to do? Your job is to keep tabs on anything alarming! Don't tell me nothing suspicious happened overnight!
I believe otherwise. Get yourself together, people! Mobilize all forces!
We're at your service, Bachelor.
Open the shop. It's been quarantined long enough. There's no danger in selling groats and grain.
Find a way to pacify the rabblerousers rioting by the shop. And do not, under any circumstances, open it!
We need to set up a spare hospital in any ordinary house. Arrange for beds and other necessary equipment to be delivered there. You know the drill.
Stay vigilant.
Your word is our command.
All right. Oh, and you mentioned an argument you were having…?
Good. As for you, stay here, and stay alert.
Have you been keeping watch all night long? Let someone else take the next shift.

Really, Doctor…? You must be overworked. What for? The Stone Yard is clear. We should know.\nAnd in any case, it's not possible. All residential houses are overcrowded with healthy refugees from across the river.
God damn you! How about the place that I'm staying at, then? It's otherwise vacant.
Shame. In that case, keep using the Cathedral for these purposes. It's not like it has other uses around here.
I think it's all because of the Polyhedron. That gravity-defying tower the children play in.
To this day, I'm confused how it's supported… Balanced, somehow? I'm not much of an engineer.
They say your children founded a republic inside. Why do your hate your own youth so much?
An impressive attempt to defy the law of gravity.

Doctor, would you mind settling an argument of ours? You are, after all, an outsider in this town, with a clear head and a fresh outlook. We've been arguing over the reasons for the sand plague outbreak. You would, of course, agree that it happened in this particular town for a reason, wouldn't you?
Indeed. I don't believe in random chance.
It could have happened anywhere.

Exactly, Bachelor. Not a single alarm. Nothing suspicious. All thanks to your iron will and the strict measures you enforced. The disease has remained across the river. Here, it's all clear. Anyone who felt weak or unwell was led to the Cathedral, but it's obvious that none of them were infected. So, will you settle our argument…?
All right, I'm all ears.
I couldn't care less for your arguments. Get back to work!
We're at your service, Bachelor.
Open the shop. It's been quarantined long enough. There's no danger in selling groats and grain.
Find a way to pacify the rabblerousers rioting by the shop. And do not, under any circumstances, open it!
We need to set up a spare hospital in any ordinary house. Arrange for beds and other necessary equipment to be delivered there. You know the drill.
Stay vigilant.
Your word is our command.
All right. Oh, and you mentioned an argument you were having…?
Good. As for you, stay here, and stay alert.
Have you been keeping watch all night long? Let someone else take the next shift.

Really, Doctor…? You must be overworked. What for? The Stone Yard is clear. We should know.\nAnd in any case, it's not possible. All residential houses are overcrowded with healthy refugees from across the river.
God damn you! How about the place that I'm staying at, then? It's otherwise vacant.
Shame. In that case, keep using the Cathedral for these purposes. It's not like it has other uses around here.

As a matter of fact, this town is nothing but a machine… produced to challenge the limits of human potential. And our ideas of how people connect to each other. Our very relationship with nature. For more than a century, the three families ruling us have been running such experiments on the local population. You've found yourself in a utopia.
Death is a limit, unjustly imposed upon men. Humanity has long outgrown it. So what exactly were you arguing about?
Don't you have better things to do? Your job is to keep tabs on anything alarming! Don't tell me nothing suspicious happened overnight!
I have found myself in hell. Get yourself together, people! Mobilize all forces!
History already knows an example of people trying to erect an impossible tower. It ended in tragedy.
It's not history. It's myth.
However, your edifice looks complete.
Do you believe in God, Bachelor?
What an unexpected twist of the conversation! Do you believe the epidemic to be a punishment from God?
No, I don't.
It may come as a surprise to you, but I do.
There's only one thing I'm certain of. If this was an ordinary, common-as-blackberries town, there'd be no outbreak. Or it'd have been something equally common and ordinary, like cholera or pox.
You may well be right. Scientifically, this is called the "butterfly effect."
Post hoc non propter hoc. Don't mix correlation and causation.

As for me, Doctor, I'd say it's simple. Men must not be remodeled or altered, even if they request it themselves. Pitied, yes, but not altered. What's wrong with men, anyway? We have so little time on this earth that it's barely possible to scratch the surface of what we are, let alone explore humanity fully. Man is infinite.
To the contrary, man is far too finite.
Exactly. We have too little time. Which is exactly why we should fight death.
But what does it have to do with the epidemic?

I don't know. I only feel that this is the root of the problem. It wasn't we who designed the world like this. I believe in men, Doctor; in superhumans, I do not. This earthly life wouldn't fit them. Immortals have no place in the world of the living. This is just how it works. Take from it what you will.
That's some fervor.
Well, it's not as absurd a line of thinking as it seems at first glance...

Doctor, would you mind settling an argument of ours? You are, after all, an outsider in this town, with a clear head and a fresh outlook. We've been arguing over the reasons for the sand plague outbreak. You would, of course, agree that it happened in this particular town for a reason, wouldn't you?
Indeed. I don't believe in random chance.
It could have happened anywhere.

Exactly, Bachelor. Not a single alarm. Nothing suspicious. All thanks to your iron will and the strict measures you enforced. The disease has remained across the river. Here, it's all clear. Anyone who felt weak or unwell was led to the Cathedral, but it's obvious that none of them were infected. So, will you settle our argument…?
All right, I'm all ears.
I couldn't care less for your arguments. Get back to work!

As a matter of fact, this town is nothing but a machine… produced to challenge the limits of human potential. And our ideas of how people connect to each other. Our very relationship with nature. For more than a century, the three families ruling us have been running such experiments on the local population. You've found yourself in a utopia.
Death is a limit, unjustly imposed upon men. Humanity has long outgrown it. So what exactly were you arguing about?
Don't you have better things to do? Your job is to keep tabs on anything alarming! Don't tell me nothing suspicious happened overnight!
I believe otherwise. Get yourself together, people! Mobilize all forces!
We're at your service, Bachelor.
Open the shop. It's been quarantined long enough. There's no danger in selling groats and grain.
Find a way to pacify the rabblerousers rioting by the shop. And do not, under any circumstances, open it!
We need to set up a spare hospital in any ordinary house. Arrange for beds and other necessary equipment to be delivered there. You know the drill.
Stay vigilant.
Your word is our command.
Good. As for you, stay here, and stay alert.
Have you been keeping watch all night long? Let someone else take the next shift.
All right. Oh, and you mentioned an argument you were having…?

Really, Doctor…? You must be overworked. What for? The Stone Yard is clear. We should know.\nAnd in any case, it's not possible. All residential houses are overcrowded with healthy refugees from across the river.
God damn you! How about the place that I'm staying at, then? It's otherwise vacant.
Shame. In that case, keep using the Cathedral for these purposes. It's not like it has other uses around here.
We would kindly suggest that any unauthorized attendants move along, please! Sorry, but our workload is tremendous.
…Who are you?
Sorry. Didn't mean to bother you.

We're here to replace the deceased. Keep tabs on the deceased. Find accomodations for the deceased. Take complaints from the deceased. If you'd like to file a complaint, please wait in line for your turn.
I think I'm going insane…
Like hell I'll wait in line!
Thank heavens, I'm still alive. And I have no intention of dying.

Every order and instruction of yours has been carried out with precision. We accept no complaints in regards to ourselves or our predecessors, not from you. If you feel dissatisfied with anything, you have no one to blame but yourself.
Indeed.
Well, it's good that you've reopened the shop. Their stock is very decent. I only wanted to thank you, is all.
The beds you've provided for the makeshift hospital are creaky. This will not do. I need to have a good night's sleep.
That was the carrier. Sure was...
What makes you think so?
Who did this?
Ain't it obvious? A shame we got him so late...!\nWhat were you thinking, doc? How'dya miss him?
You will pay for this.
I can't believe it...
Them savages are the root of all evil. Who else could bring the pest with 'em? Plain as day, it is.
You imbeciles. He had nothing to do with it.
Don't you have enough sins to atone for already? Did you really need one more? It's not like you've got much time left. Get lost and go home.

Good riddance to the plague-bearer... He did it. He brought the pest. There's no one else that could.\nShould burn their steppe den down too... Gather the good people at night, light us some torches and burn it to hell and back!
What?
You won't live to see the night. Trust me, I'm a doctor.
For real! Shouldn't have let them in here in the first place. That was your doing! We know everything.\nYou deserve no better, Worm-lover!
Well, all men are mortal.
Calm down. And get lost. Or else...
See? Totes waiting here! And you doubted me, too! Here, your share, take it. Fair and square, share and share alike. Half to you, half to me.
...This isn't even close to a half!
I'm impressed—I wasn't expecting to see you here at all. Are your parents alive?
Here. Your share, fair and square. There was also a bottle of some sort of "pana serum", got smashed.
Damn you! ...Do you have any idea what a "panacea" is? That bottle was worth more than your weight in diamonds!
Oh no... You little lying rat... Give it here, now!
Dunno what you're talking about. I did my best to divide by two.
Which makes you an incredibly lousy arithmetician. You belong to a school, boy, not to the street, burgling drugstores.
Should have foreseen this...
Nope, orphaned. Hey, will you take me in?
I'll think about it.
Like I need you... go bother Burakh.
I'm not lying, I swear! Here are the pieces, look!
...Indeed.
Well, perhaps there's more at the store...? Go ahead, I'll wait.
Get lost. Now.
It was a serum that could cure the sand pest. Enough for several lives, perhaps. Unique, too. There's no one left to make more...
Well...? What are you waiting for? C'mon, I ain't got all day!
I won't have you hurry me up, you shameless little...!
You keep standing there. Patience builds character.
...I have a very important thing to ask of you.\nDon't listen to Shrew, okay? And never ever give her nuts. It's all a trap. Got it?
I most certainly didn't.
Why? I thought rodents like nuts.
...Right. What are you lot doing here?
How's Blacky?
He's fine. But his stepfather died.
Were you the person who sent the orderly to his flat?
Of course not.
Thought so.
Speaking of orderlies—one of them reported you lot making yourself busy with something rather shady. I'm looking forward to hearing you explain yourselves.
Shrew wants you to die. Don't give her anything.
Shrew? You mean the pig-tails girl? Have I wronged her somehow?

Not at all. She just thinks your whole ordeal is wrong—and feels sorry for you. Thing is, I don't want you to die.\nYou know what? If you find any nuts, bring them to me instead. I'll give you anything in exchange! How about bandages? You're a doctor, you probably need those.
What's up with this nut obsession of yours! If you're hungry, how about some bread?
Bandages? Why do you even have them? In any case, wouldn't it be responsible of you to just give them to me? Without the nut fee?
They're not food! They're for the dead! Look there—why do you think Sleepy Head is standing by the windows with pocketfuls of nuts?
Exactly. Why is he?
Sleepy Head over there is is waiting for the departing to depart. Soon they will. It's a game of ours.
"The departing"? You mean someone's dying inside...?
You kids play peculiar games...

A couple of good masters used to live here, fine-tuners. Sleepy Head wants them to advise him after they die. Nuts can preserve people after death. So Shrew wanted to scrounge one from Sleepy Head for you, but he won't give her any.
For me?
I'd like to have a word with your peers now...
Look, just don't give nuts to Shrew, all right? Give them to me instead. I don't want you to die. You can keep living with us. Teach me, too... I want to be a doctor, y'know.
If you want to be a doctor, start by removing this ridiculous nonsense you seem to believe in from your head.
Here. Will this kind of nut do?
Just don't tell Shrew I warned you, 'right? We're good friends, actually...
As if you warned me of something important. I wouldn't be able to explain your babbling to anyone even if I wanted to...
Here you go. The nuts.
The only thing that made sense in your story was that you kids are all starved for nuts.
Do you have any bandages left? Or other useful supplies? Help me out, my faithful squire.
Do you really, honestly want to die? Are you bored of us?
No. I don't intend to die anytime soon.
Dead bored.
I see... Tell me, doctor: do you know where you are? Right now, I mean?
In the unluckiest town on earth.
Honestly, no idea. Your town is like a maze, and I'm yet to learn to tell the districts apart.
Yes. I'm at a loss. Should I simply stop giving you attention or should I spice it up with a spanking first?

You are in your room right now, laying in bed, feverish. Sleepy Head and Shrew are there too. We give you water and put wet towels on your forehead, just like you told us to... It's good that you can at least hear me now. Answer even.
It's "lying in bed", not "laying", blockhead. When this is all over, you really need to go to school...
Curious. So are you telling me you didn't wake me up in the morning?
Over... Yeah, it will be over soon, for you at least. Shouldn't have given Shrew nuts.
Well, what's done is done. Now let me go. I'm in a hurry,
You play stupid games...
I did. But it was yesterday. What time is it now?
I don't know. I've lost my watch.
Not the right one for silly banter! Excuse me, I have urgent business to attend to.
It's almost midnight. You're dying. I didn't want you to die. Even if you're bed-ridden and raving, living is still better than dying... And you know so much interesting stuff, too...
Very funny. Now please excuse me, I would like to resume my work, if that's fine by you.
Then keep giving me water and doing the wet towel thing. And thank you for taking good care of me.
You must feel terrible... right? That's fine. I forgive you.\nYou just got confused... Adults always do.
Oh yes, adults are always occupied with the most asinine nonsense. Like feeling anxious that a bunch of urchins keep roaming the streets, putting themselves in mortal danger!
I do feel terrible... for some reason. What I wouldn't give for a gulp of water...
Yes, doctor. I know you're worried about the sand pest. But we're safe.\nNo, really, we are. So calm down. It's all right.
Go home. All three of you.
Not convinced.
Don't you need lockpicks anymore? Good. I agree that you don't.
I need to make sure you are all safe. It's called "being responsible." Another boring thing that adults do.
Oh right, slipped my mind completely... Wait some more then.
Shrew's got the keys. Not me. I don't need to go in there anyway. One can catch 'em from over here just fine.
What's in there?
Catch whom?

Two solid masters are dying in there right now, Siskin and Lotman. Both have been over the river, so now they're done for. That's what you get for getting carried away! Anyway. I want to collect them into nuts. I'll listen to 'em before I go to sleep 'n they'll advise me.
So this is what you need nuts for?
Collect them into nuts? How?
Let me check if I got everything right. What you're saying is there are two infected persons in that house. Correct?
I don't need 'em. Got a handful already. It's Shrew who's trying to cajole 'em out of everyone. Well, in my case, fat chance!
And what does she need them for?
And who are Siskin and Lotman?
Nah, they probs just cut 'emselves or something. But you won't get inside anyway. The house is locked.
Well, how do I unlock it?

You don't. And I wouldn't tell you if I knew anyway. You'll come back here with 'em beakheads, drag Siskin 'n Lotman to the mortuary, 'n kick me out of here. Right? So how am I going to collect 'em into nuts then? Nah man. You're barking up the wrong tree if you think you can trick me like that.
Well, I'll find a way in without your help then.
"Collect them into nuts"? What do you mean?
A nut is a tricky fruit. It resonates. If you do everything properly, you can preserve a person inside. Got it? Talk to him after death 'n all. Through a teeny tiny hole. If he agrees to, I mean.
A nut is not a fruit, you blockhead. The rest sounds reasonable though.
What if he doesn't?
For you, as far as I know. You're about to kick the bucket too, ain't you? And Shrew likes you. Wants to have you in her collection.
In her collection? Explain yourself.
Well, then you wait for him to get bored. It's probably super tiresome sitting inside a nut talking to no one. Eternal life must be tedious.
Yes... Unless you're evolving.
Clearly you have a lot of experience in such matters.

Oooh, they were master hexers! Knew how to hoodwink time into bringing luck. Cast such an awesome spell over my pocket knife that I used to win with it every time! Never cut myself, too. Anyway, they tried a lotta things. Like going 'cross the river... I know that business demanded it, but still. A shame.
So what, are you waiting for them to peek out of the window?
I'm waiting for them to die. Don't want their mastery to go to waste.
What? This makes no sense,
Just... dontcha worry, 'kay? 'Twill be over soon.
You three loafers need to go and find yourselves a good safe shelter.
Impudent little brats, aren't you?
...Why is it so hot here?
Aye, no point arguing with you anyway. We'll come in a sec—just let us finish watching the important part of the action here.
No "secs"! You're all grounded! I don't need any more bandages or lockpicks—just leave!
You finish your... whatever it is you're doing—and then get off the street at once. All right?
Well? Have you collected them?
Collected what?
What are you rascals doing here?
The nuts! You promised to get us nuts.
...What do you need nuts for?
Will candy do?
"Promised"? When? I've never seen you before.
How many times have I told you it's none of your business? Must be a hundred times. Or two hundred.\nI need them, simple as that.
You're mistaking me for someone else, girl.
Well, I don't. Need this fuss, I mean.
Doctor, are you sure you're all right? Suppose you've gotten sick yourself?\nThey say the sick ones start to rave and don't recognize their family and can't remember who they are.
Mind your manners!
It's just as they say. The first symptom of the sand plague is madness. Strange behaviour. And your behaviour seems very strange to me!

...Let me say it again. We had a deal. You can go everywhere, I can't go anywhere, thanks loads for that.\nRight?\nThat's why you get me nuts, and I give you whatever you need in exchange. Like lockpicks. Handmade. Rare. A super luxurious product, if you ask me!
What I need is for you to stop hanging around with no one overseeing you.
All right then. Let's honor the deal. I'll try to bring you nuts. Although it feels like the one who's nuts is me...
Oh, no need to be shy. You can't go anywhere? With a pocketful of rare luxurious handmade lockpicks? Right. Perhaps it would be safer for me to have them.
Sound like a deal. Here, have a nut.
No way. And anyway, it's we who are overseeing you. You're dreaming us anyway. Got it?
Nice try.
Look, we'll go wherever you want us to go. We'll be good kids. But the nut deal comes first.
All right. I'll consider it.
Honestly, I don't need nuts to get you locked up if I decide to. Just like that.
Well, seems like I have a couple... Lucky you. Or me.
No! How many times do I have to explain, I'm not going to eat them! They're alive.
What do you mean, "alive"?
Those are some right suspicious games you're playing... I don't like that at all.
I sullenly swear. Heavens, sevens, now and forevance.
Good.
When I was your age, the thing to say was "I shall eat earth." But that's unhygienic, so no matter. I trust you.
Wrong! You need the keys, don't you? The keys to this house, I mean, the one where everybody's dying. But unless you bring me nuts, you'll get no lockpicks! None at all! Got it?
What? People are dying inside this house? What makes you think so?
You have lockpicks...? Give them to me. Now. We're dealing with a matter of public safety here.

Keeping vigil. Waiting for the things inside the house to come to a close. Also for nuts.\nI'll be generous enough to forgive the "rascals" for now. I can even help you get inside. If you bring me a nut, of course.
...Why do you need nuts?
"Come to a close"? What are you talking about...?

Oh god... It's true what they say: what can you expect from a hog but a grunt? ...All right. Whatever. You've never seen me before. I'll go with that.\nKind uncle doctor, can you get me some nuts, pretty please? I need them so so badly! And, actually, so do you. Even worse than me.
Are you kids cutting teeth or something?
I need it worse than you? You don't know what you're saying, young lady.
I don't want to talk about it. I'm scared. Let Sleepy Head tell you.
I see... Now hand over the lockpicks. Do it! Or the keys, or what have you.
You're frightening me.
Perhaps. But...
...Only in exchange for nuts. Got it already. Trading one-for-one, right?
...Get better soon, doctor. And I'm so sorry for you.
I'm fine, thank you. Your whole town, on the other hand, needs help. Direly.
Here. The nuts. Is this enough?
Thanks for the concern. Now, about those lockpicks...
...Get better soon, doctor. And I'm so sorry for you.
I'm fine, thank you. Your whole town, on the other hand, needs help. Direly.
Here. The nuts. Is this enough?
Thanks for the concern. Now, about those lockpicks...
So here's how it's gonna be with you, huh! Well, in that case, you're no friend of mine!
What did I do to lose your favor?
So when Sticky asks you for nuts, you're all too happy to run his errand and oblige, huh? And I'm second-class?\nDo you even know why he doesn't want me to help you?
Oh, I didn't realize you wanted to help. In that case, please be so kind as to fetch a bucket of hot water from my place. Chop-chop.
No, I don't. Why?

You dummy doctor. Ugh, I can't even look at you. So miserable... Lying in your bed, feverish and unconscious, you honestly still believe you're walking the town. Hot water, you say? Why would you need it hot when one can roast eggs on your forehead anyway!
What in the world are you talking about?

...This is pointless. Look, everyone, here's what a person whose mind was erased by sickness looks like... You are delirious, doctor. Raving. Do you understand? You're sick. Got infected with the sand plague! And so you're hallucinating. It's midnight now, and we're at your place, looking after you!
I don't feel sick at all.
Well, I'd say it's you who seems to be raving, girl. And that is a very suspicious symptom. You'll have to come with me.

Because he doesn't want to let you pass away like normal people do! 'Cause you two are BFFs now or something! He wants to learn stuff from you! And so he clings to you, sticks to you, cures you, and generally plays doctor. Moron. You need to have a pillow stuffed over your face and your soul stuffed into a nut. For safekeeping.
Seems like it's you who's nuts.
You clearly have a very kind and compassionate heart. I'll try to make do without the pillow though, all right?

Pffft, yeah, right. Go with you? Where to? The afterlife? No thank you. You'll have to manage on your own. And since you've failed to bring me a nut, there won't be even a single shred of you staying here. Serves you right, too! You're no friend of mine now.
Well, in that case, you're no friend of mine either.
It's not like I don't feel sorry for you. Perhaps I'll even deign to help you after all. But I'll never ever ask you for help again, no sir!
It's dangerous outside. You should all go home.
What's important is whether I will help you, not the other way round.
...Will you look at this guy, boys? Huh? He still thinks we're all standing somewhere outside!
Chop-chop.
I have no intention to play games with you.
Pfft. All right then. We'll go. And you won't have anyone to barter with anymore.
I'll live.
Huh, didn't consider that. Come to think of it, there's no need for you to hurry.
I've already taken heart. Taken a heart, I mean. Undoubtedly, an open one.
He needs to live. Let him suffer. Just not die today.
I'll do what I can.
We'll see.
Everything will be good now. We are grateful to you.
How can anyone deal with your people and preserve their sanity?! What happened...?
Never seen better...
She was a herb bride. Brides join Earth in wedlock, so that the others may live.\nIt means no one else will die today. You are the doctor. We did this for you.
You are an insane, barbaric people! How can you live with yourself?!
So this is what kind of wedding you were celebrating...! Why oh why didn't I listen to the poor wounded guy...
We fear neither pain nor death. One is immortal while the kin lives.\nYou wouldn't understand.
Yeah, it's Greek to me...
If only it was so simple. But I doubt that millions of dying people would agree with you.

If there'd been mourning, the celebration would have been cancelled. If the celebration had been cancelled, the earth would have gone unfed.\nWhen the earth isn't fed, it feeds itself. And that would be far worse. No one would be saved.
Are you talking about the plague...? What does it have to do with the earth?
You don't care about your husband's life at all, do you?
Well. No one will be saved now...
You've suffered a great loss. I'm sorry.
Doctors don't always end up being winners in their duels with death.
Really? Why?
Mother Boddho gives us no respite. The earth is calling. Such is our fate then.\nFrom the soil we came, and to the soil we return. As for you, go. We need to prepare ourselves.
I'm sorry.
I learned of this place too late.
You've almost come to. See? We've been here all along.
What is this banging noise?
I see, yes. You lot are way too sneaky. Which is why I'll have to lock you in this room—just to be safe.
What noise? ...Are you okay?
You lot shouldn't be here...
Whatever. Now let me through.
Look y'all, he's waking up... What if he attacks us? I'd say we make a run for it!
You're running nowhere, I'll make sure of that. You will be locked in and boarded shut... for your own safety.
I don't think you'd manage to even of you tried, lad. I think we've been boarded in.
Saturday
We're not allowed to talk today. There's a celebration.
Well... congratulations, I guess.
Mikhail Goba, orderly No. 2. Awaiting your command, doctor...
Why did you come?
Firstly, I need a team of orderlies here, stat. Board off the house. Don't let anyone out... myself included. I'm staying in there. I have likely contracted the disease.
Graveman
Everything can change. Would you want it?
Who are you?
Where am I?
Of course I would. It can't get any worse anyway.
I am a shepherd.
A shame. I think I'm in need of a doctor. A good one. Better than myself...
So you're shepherding me, huh?
Home.
This is not my home.
I don't like this place.
How do I get back to the town?
Everything can change. Would you want it?
Of course I would. Who wouldn't...
No. I'm fine it as it is.
Take a footpath. But you don't need to go there.
Thank you. Farewell.
Are you a fortune-teller?
Orderly No. 12. Arrived here at your behest, doc. I was there, by the fire. I see that you clearly are alive. Who cares what the legal papers say. It's not like I can read anyway...
Are you the chief orderly?
...This is the first time in my life that I can appreciate the usefulness of illiteracy. Why no cloak though? Aren't you afraid of the infection?
Nah. I'm a boatman. I used to take people across the river before the plague broke out.\nNow I'm here to keep on working, doc. I'm just standing my watch.
All right. Have some rest. I can see you're on your last legs.
Go. Your watch is over.
Keep standing then...
I am, doc. But I need my hands free...
Whatever. It's too late now anyway.
You're out of line, number twelve. If you leave this house, you'll have to put it on.
Think 'tis time I began, eh, doc?
Began what? It's all over now. We're done.
Who are you?
Orderly No. 12. Arrived here at your behest, doc. I was there, by the fire. I see that you clearly are alive. Who cares what the legal papers say. It's not like I can read anyway...
You came too late.
Why aren't you wearing a cloak?
Well, what can one do... The bodies need to be moved around, that requires free hands. See, doc... There, uh... were people. Came seeking your help. You won't here, so, well... What can one do...
Take the children to a spare room and board them off. Seal them shut so that not a single infected soul could get in. Got it?
Then move the bodies wherever they need moving, number twelve. Be my guest...
I'm doing my best to hurry, doctor, sir, I really am. Dismantling these bloody things takes time. But we're doing it.\nThey truly are disturbing.
Are you dismantling signal fires? Why the hell? Who gave the order?
Stop. Leave it.

Erm... Well, it's not like anyone needs them anymore, sir. And it's getting colder by the day. October is at hand.\nMeans houses need heating. And wood is scarce in these parts... what with us living amidst a steppe and all.
Leave it, I'm telling you.
Don't you worry, you'll get warm in the evening when all the dead bodies will pile up and require moving around.

You are indeed a learned and venerable man, sir... not one to indulge in superstition. But wouldn't we be croaking disaster if we keep them? Dismantling the unnerving things would be best. But it'll be as you wish, of course. I'm just following orders.
I wish you would stop stepping out of line and prepare yourself for the worst.
If no outbreak happens by the evening, you'll light it up to celebrate.
Bite your tongue, doctor, sir! Erm, pardon me. But we've had enough dead bodies already, half the town is gone.\nThat's it. No more suffering. Now is the time to live.
Half the town, huh? According to my information, you're severely underestimating the extent of the catastrophe.
If you want to live, you have to listen to me! And I'm telling you that you're loosening safety measures prematurely.

The fires turned out to be handy, doctor, sir! Your expectations came true. Truly, you have a brilliant mind.\nI've been asked to remind you of the appointment you have for today's evening. By God's mercy, perhaps it'll also go smoothly...
Who are you?
You've been asked? By whom? How do you know my appointments?
I'm just standing my watch. Come, little birds, and gather around the marble nest!
Damn you to hell.
I've always hated marble...
Shar Shuvuu
Shar Shuvuu
Hah! Thanks, Doc! You sure hit two birds with one stone there!
What birds?
