You gave the sick over to the orderlies!\nMeans, first off, they won't suffer. Second, the residence can be freshened up, cleaned—and moved into, like new! Third, the orderlies are busy with them, so they won't touch us…\nThree birds, I suppose.
Like hell you'll freshen up anything! That house needs to be burned down. Or at least boarded shut if fire isn't an option. And even then, never approached without protective clothes.
Any particular reason for you to draw the orderlies' attention? Come closer, show me your tongue…
Calm down, Doc! I'm fine. Just sayin'…
"Just sayin'" doesn't seem to be working out all that brilliantly for you.
Kindest sir! Fairy godfather!\nCan I call you "godfather" now…?
What are you talking about, old man? I'm young enough to be your son.
Please don't. My relations to the local people are purely professional.
But it makes sense! You took us in… Sheltered us. Ordered to bring the sick to your own house! To close the eyes of the dying with your own hand, to give them final solace with your own prayer…
It's not my house. It's a temporary residence. As for the sick, I was driven by rational considerations. Simpler this way.
I truly hope I won't have to close anyone's eyes, and that my own hand will offer the patients broth and oats.
Thank you… Thank you… They say that you don't have a heart, but I always knew that you do!
An exquisite compliment indeed.
If you only knew, old man…
Ugh, I'm starving… Barely standing, too.
Yes, I'm ravenous, too. Haven't had anything filling in a while… I think I'll faint if I don't eat in an hour.
I'm sorry, but I don't have anything to share with you. If I gave you the bare necessities I have, I'd kick the bucket myself.
…Now we burn the Cathedral down, right?\nIt's there you're heading, ain't it? To give the order?
You're a fervent theomachist, I take it?
No. We burn nothing down. We protect local architecture and execute arsonists. That's what we do. Got it?

Well, I mean… You ordered everyone who so much as sniffled be dragged there, didn't you? Locked them up, let 'em stew, didn't you?\nStands to reason, I think, the only thing left to do is burn the place down and be done with the stinkin' sand pest.
Commendable resolve. Do your friends share these ideas?
I ordered suspicious people there, not the sick. To be tended to, not locked up. And don't get me started on the rest of your ideas!\nGive you people an inch of rope…
Eh. The folks and I saved some kerosene for you. Need it?
No. Go home and lock yourself in.
Sorry, I have to go. Need to get to the Cathedral before your kind friends show up there with the kerosene.

I think I should apologize for how angry we were at you… We thought the draconian security measures were put in place indefinitely.\nBut I've been told that the restrictions were canceled this morning. Does that imply unblocking the bridges too? Unnerving…
"You've been told"? By whom?
Keep being angry. The protective measures are here to stay. I even intend to tighten them.

That's the rumor. The order came through this morning. Who could issue it? Obviously it was either you or Judge Kain—with your consent. Or maybe your assistants at the headquarters over at the Crucible. You must have had a hand in this… Are the rumors false, then?
They must be. I ordered no such thing. Couldn't happen without my consent, either.
The only world where they could be true is a world where I'm a sleepwalker who issued the orders in his sleep. Even then I wouldn't dream of it, really. In other words, this is nonsense.
So what, we go back to work? With that stinkin' plague defeated an' all?\nMeans I have to return to the factory, is that it?
What makes you say so?
Isn't your factory across the river, in the very center of the outbreak?
You're right. So how do I get back to work, then?
Here's how: Go to the nearest soldier and explain you're a volunteer willing to fix barricades. Got it? Then off you are.
Well, calamity's over, ain't it? Hence my questions an' all.
If only it were so simple…
Bored without work? Go to the Crucible, then. You'll find recruiters right outside, top of the stairs. Volunteer as an orderly. They'll give you the proper equipment.
So will medicine be delivered by you now? I need spirits.
Spirits to raise your spirits? No. Sanitizers cost their weight in gold now.
What medicine are you talking about, old man? I don't even have the resources to properly dress a scratch.
Resources are distributed by the headquarters, under the Judge's supervision. Haven't you been informed?

So what of it, wasn't it you who ordered the drugstore locked up…? Us commonfolk are afraid to go there, never mind that it's on the outskirts.\nNo meds in the headquarters, no meds in possession. And them soldier lads won't give us none. So how do we get better? Ain't God's way, this.
Why do you need medicine so badly? Let me look at your pupils…
I never gave such an order. They're abusing their power. Thank you for voicing your concern.
Come now, Doc! I'm healthy!\nOnly asking for my fellow man.
Right. And to raise your spirits…
No one in this town is healthy. Not in every sense of the word.

The Crucible is off limits. The ark is full. Those who have been taken on board by the Judge will probably be saved. As for me, a mutt's death for a mutt. Dying in the street… Oh well. Ain't worse than dying anywhere.
There are other places to seek shelter. The Cathedral, for example.
Only those who don't bury themselves ahead of time will survive.
Like anyone can find salvation in that place!
Nothing is over yet. This is just the beginning. I've been told to relay that to everyone.
Doctor, you look exhausted! You need to take better care of yourself. I'd invite you to offer you dinner, but I've got nothing to share…
You're quite right, I do need to eat. Don't worry, I'll find something.
I'm sorry to hear that.
They say the quarantine has been lifted. Are we free now? Is it permitted to cross the river?
"They say" is half a lie. You shouldn't trust random rumors. The quarantine will only be lifted when I let it be lifted.
"Across the river" equals "to a better world" these days, darling. Yes, you're free to go if you're in such a hurry.

You should tell this to your beakheaded orderlies, then. They've abandoned their duties—meaning someone let them go.\nPeople expect the refugee shelters to be unlocked any moment now. They used to be our homes, after all. Is it true? When will it happen?
This came out of the blue…
…Over my dead body. The same applies to going across the river, too. Tell that to your friends.
People were evicted from three houses yesterday. They must have left food behind. When is it going to be distributed?
Evicted? How? Why?
I suspect you are mistaken. Each household was provided three days worth of food for the isolation period. The bare minimum. So I very much doubt there's anything edible left anywhere.
I don't know. But there may be goods inside, and those houses stand deserted anyway. So why won't they let us in?

And where were the evicted people relocated, I wonder? It's not like there are spare houses in the Stone Yard. When we were trying to accommodate the refugees from across the river, people were packed like sardines. Some of them even had to sleep outside.
Perhaps you're right, there may be food left there. I'll take a look. Which particular houses are you talking about? Who do they belong to?
I don't know, doctor. It's said the owners have gone back across the river. The whole ordeal is over, isn't it? Doesn't this mean our own guests will also be evicted soon?
I want to take a look personally. Where are these houses? They're guarded, I should hope?
No. It won't happen anytime soon. You'll have to be patient.

I don't know. Rumor has it, there are soldiers standing watch. Even if there's no food left, perhaps we can at least move refugees there?\nI mean really, Doctor! My own house is so packed, there's no room to swing a cat! And you've forbidden them from going outside, too…
I've forbidden everyone from going outside. Yourself included. But my words seem to fall on deaf ears…
Soldiers… Well, that's reassuring, at least. The last thing we need is looters.
So, Dankovsky, did you find that thief of yours?
What thief?
"A thief of mine"? You must have taken me for someone else. I do not number thieves and pirates among my acquaintance.
This night, a disheveled man broke into Judge Kain's house. Kicked up quite a racket…\nHe begged the Judge to hide him from you. Pleaded for justice. Everyone assumes he stole something from you.
He asked the Judge for justice? I wonder if he expects me to shoot first and ask questions later.
So lovely of him to go straight to a judge after that. It's nice to see people of high moral values.
I don't know. Perhaps. He must have had his reasons.
…Ah! I see. I think I know why that man was scared of me. I suspect I've found what I've been looking for.
I'm a doctor, not a criminal. If I caught a thief, I would most likely offer him food and shelter.
Perhaps… I think a visit to the Judge is in order.

When a person lives in one place for a long time, they imbue it with their soul. Even after they die, the particles remain, filling the place.\nIt's good you locked down the houses of the deceased, and forbid anyone from moving in there.
Who told you that? I'm very much in favor of resettlement.
As if there were tenants to move in…

The tenant of the Stillwater died some time ago and was never infected, yet her mansion remains untouched. Thank you!\nWhen I walk by it, I sometimes hear her voice. That means that everything is all right.
Never been better.
It can't be. You're imagining things.
Have you ever considered going to a fortune-teller? To learn your fate, maybe even see tomorrow?
Palmistry, tarot, reading entrails? I don't appreciate obscurantism.
No. Never. Remember Macbeth?
No. These kinds of people always try to astonish the audience by predicting their date of death. And in my case, they'd be mistaken.
Any help or advice would be appreciated now. Even that from an augur or a haruspex.
A mime performance is being staged in front of the Cathedral. A tragic one.\nThe actors are, not unexpectedly, quite silent, but if you manage to get one to talk…
A tragic performance that will predict my fate? Sounds reassuring.
Tragic, huh? Indeed, it must be hard to watch the local attempts at drama without weeping,
Don't worry. You'll like it.
Like I would worry about some backwater theatre.
I hope they return the money if the audience hasn't experienced catharsis…
It's been three days and we're yet to see a single sick person here in the Stone Yard. To think that the plague was spreading like wildfire before! Yet somehow you managed to stop it… Incredible.
Don't give all the credit to me. A lot of people worked their fingers to the bone helping out.
There's nothing to be incredulous about. Diligent measures, unflinching control, strict discipline… That's all it takes.
Earth and the Middle were more crowded… and chaotic. Working here was much easier.
Have you seen them? Rats everywhere, thousands of rats! What does it mean…? It can't be here already, can it?
Calm down! It doesn't mean anything yet.
I have… To think that I almost believed that we may have indeed won. Idiot!
Why didn't you take in the boy? He'll become an urchin now.\nDon't you realize what he'll turn into? What he'll be doing in a week's time?
What boy?
You examined the late Blacker. But you didn't bother with the fate of his stepson.
I'll be thrilled if he's still alive to engage in petty thievery in a week's time.
I'm a doctor, not a sister of mercy. Urchins and orphans are the local authorities' responsibility.
He's probably smashing someone's windows right now. Who will reimburse that damage? You?
You're a moron. Out of my way!
Please address your concerns about broken windows to the headquarters at the Crucible or the Judge personally. As for your stunning lack of consideration, do find a confessor.
Please allow me to shake your hand.
To what do I owe the pleasure?
I was mistaken about you. You are the only brave person in this town.
I'm flattered.
Are you trying to borrow money from me or something?

A maneater should never pretend to be a mouse. He should wield his bloodstained cleaver proudly. Issuing the order regarding the suspects in the Cathedral was a straightforward and candid action.\nHopefully you witnessed the… display… in person?
I gave no such order.
Do you think doing my duty is fun?
What display?

Stop trying to wriggle your way out. There's nothing more nauseating than a person attempting to cast away their vocation.\nA natural-born hangman makes for a lousy rope weaver. Just work with the material fate gives you.
Go to hell.
By the Cathedral. You ought to have a look.
I have no idea what you're talking about.
What do you call a person who first announces that the epidemic is curbed and then immediately sets up hospital in their very house?
I'd call such a person diligent and considerate.
Brave.
I'd call him human and thus capable of making mistakes. For example, just now he mistook you for a decent person. Farewell.
And I'd call them a two-faced viper who fed people false hope.
It's better to take hope away when catastrophe looms than to cling to illusions, leading everyone to their graves.
Let us rejoice, then: No one has asked for your opinion.
No. It is not.
Whatever,
A hungry soldier is a lousy soldier. Man does nothing right on an empty stomach. When are they going to open the shops again? When will food be distributed?
Oh, thanks for reminding me. I think I need to have a bite… or else I might faint of hunger.
I don't know. Deal with it.

I think I should apologize for how angry we were at you… We thought the draconian security measures were put in place indefinitely.\nBut I've been told that the restrictions were canceled this morning. Does that imply unblocking the bridges too? Unnerving…"
"You've been told"? By whom?
Keep being angry. The protective measures are here to stay. I even intend to tighten them.

That's the rumor. The order came through this morning. Who could issue it? Obviously it was either you or Judge Kain—with your consent. Or maybe your assistants at the headquarters over at the Crucible. You must have had a hand in this… Are the rumors false, then?
They must be. I ordered no such thing. Couldn't happen without my consent, either.
The only world where they could be true is a world where I'm a sleepwalker who issued the orders in his sleep. Even then I wouldn't dream of it, really. In other words, this is nonsense.
A masquerade ball will be held in the main square this evening. People want to celebrate our victory over the sand pest. You don't mind…?
Of course I do. Is the average age in this town five?
How about burying your dead first? People want to celebrate, my ass…
I seem to vaguely remember a rather famous story about a masquerade held to celebrate a victory over a plague. Remember how it ended?
Religious buildings often have thick walls. Why, I wonder? So that the holy spirit won't flutter out?
Monasteries often serve as prisons.
Do not blaspheme against the Holy Spirit. Even I know that, and I'm agnostic.
So that worldly desires won't creep in.

In any case, it works in your favor. Thick walls contain moans and screams effectively.\nThis is why you ordered to drag everyone suspicious to the Cathedral, isn't it? So that everything would seem fine from the outside?
No cheating your eagle eye though.
No. The people who show suspicious signs are taken to the Cathedral because no one in the Town attends the place.
If I were you, I'd hurry up with the inspection. One day, so many people will be mured up there that the walls won't be able to hold.
What would I do without your sagely advice?
I'll check on the place.
Time is coming to an end. But that's fine. We'll manage without it just fine.
Clearly you have no appreciation of how the world works. All of you. An insane, disjointed town!
What?
It has all been in vain. The plague has gotten to us here. The Neck and Mallet districts are already poisoned.
Don't give up. There were survivors across the river. Seven, I believe. That's a lot.
This is all your fault. I did everything I could.
Doctor, did you know that a terrified man snuck into Judge Kain's place this night? He begged the Judge to hide him.
Hide? From whom?
What scared the poor soul so much?
I don't care. The Judge has every right to invite whoever he pleases to his house.
…He implored the Judge to hide and protect him from you, Doctor.
…And? Did the Judge agree?
Curious… So this is why the Judge wanted to see me this morning.
Well, I don't know the details. I just thought I should tell…\nI'm not an informer. But now is not the time for secrets. Too much is at stake, wouldn't you agree?
Absolutely. You did the right thing.
Thank you, kind sir. Let us hope the Judge refused to hide the man. That would simplify my search a lot.
You know, you really shouldn't have done this. It's hard to respect a snitch, however valuable his information.
You look ready to drop, Doctor. Why do you refuse to take care of yourself? When was the last time you had a bite to eat?
I don't remember… You're right, I probably should.
Touching. Now please mind your own business and move along.
People were evicted from three houses yesterday. They must have left food behind. When is it going to be distributed?
Evicted? How? Why?
I suspect you are mistaken. Each household was provided three days worth of food for the isolation period. The bare minimum. So I very much doubt there's anything edible left anywhere.
I don't know. But there may be goods inside, and those houses stand deserted anyway. So why won't they let us in?

And where were the evicted people relocated, I wonder? It's not like there are spare houses in the Stone Yard. When we were trying to accommodate the refugees from across the river, people were packed like sardines. Some of them even had to sleep outside.
Perhaps you're right, there may be food left there. I'll take a look. Which particular houses are you talking about? Who do they belong to?
I don't know, doctor. It's said the owners have gone back across the river. The whole ordeal is over, isn't it? Doesn't this mean our own guests will also be evicted soon?
I want to take a look personally. Where are these houses? They're guarded, I should hope?
No. It won't happen anytime soon. You'll have to be patient.

I don't know. Rumor has it, there are soldiers standing watch. Even if there's no food left, perhaps we can at least move refugees there?\nI mean really, Doctor! My own house is so packed, there's no room to swing a cat! And you've forbidden them from going outside, too…
I've forbidden everyone from going outside. Yourself included. But my words seem to fall on deaf ears…
Soldiers… Well, that's reassuring, at least. The last thing we need is looters.
Thank you for lifting the quarantine, Doctor. This means we've managed to outlive the worst, doesn't it? No more suffering?
What do you mean "lifting the quarantine"? I did no such thing.
Not only have I not lifted it, I'm planning to tighten security measures.

Oh… But the soldiers abandoned the square—I saw them leave myself. They say the shop reopened… Those terrible orderlies, disbanded… Rumor has it, an order came through, canceling your prior instructions.
This is absurd. You've been misinformed, good lady.
Who could have issued such an order? As far as I know, neither Judge Kain nor the people in the anti-epidemic committee are prone to sabotage.

My husband's been dragged to the isolation ward in the Cathedral. He needs to be let go, Doctor!\nWhy are people still confined there? There's no need for them to be, what with the disease having been eliminated and all!
There is a need, dear. A pressing one, at that. This is the only way to prevent infection from spreading. So don't pester me with this issue.
The orderlies are keeping your best interests at heart.

You shameless butchers! You've seized my husband, and a dozen more with him… Perfectly healthy people! Pure as the driven snow!\nMy husband doesn't even get colds! His cough is due to the coal dust. He works at the railroad station!
Well, clearly if he's invulnerable to colds, the sand plague isn't a threat to him, either. Get off my back.
I can't make exceptions. The rules are the same for everyone. Dura lex, sed lex.
I've gambled my soul away.
Now that's a stake…
So who has it now?
Oh! And where do they gamble for souls? I'd like to have a word with the owner of the establishment.

They left their stupid Theatre behind, across the river, and now idle away at the square in front of the bloody Cathedral. I wonder how they got here in the first place…?\nBut they won't accept your bet. To each their own, as the saying goes…
Keep your chin up, my friend. You've been swindled—there's nothing more to it. It's not so easy to extract a person's soul.
True. To each their own.
Oh, you managed to prevail over the sand plague. If not for you, we'd all be six feet under.\nDoesn't this mean the worst is over? The infection won't come back…?
You are safe as long as you follow my instructions. For one, I ordered everyone to stay in and refrain from aimless wandering.
Epidemics are timeless. Of course it will come back someday.
The Tanners
The Maw
The Hindquarters
The Cemetery
The Skinners
Polyhedron
The Bridge Square
The Cape
The Abattoir
Shekhen
The Spleen
The Station
The Chine
The Flank
The Marrow
The Crude Sprawl
Warehouses
Steppe
The Atrium
The Gut
The Factory
There are soldiers guarding the drugstore—the one by the bridge, I mean. Won't let anyone in. Means they'll open it soon, right?
They'll open it when I tell them to. Not a minute earlier, not a minute later.
There are soldiers at the drugstore…? Interesting. Well, they probably have a reason to be there.
